I met the ambassador, Richard Smith, in Beijing after my visit to Tibet, and we talked about his visit to Drachi prison, where, indeed, the nun I have just spoken about languishes today. He took tea in the garden with the criminal—that is, the governor of the prison; it is the innocents on the other side of the wall. But the world prefers not to look at this.

I get the Chinese literature on Tibet, including a glossy journal called China's Tibet. It is full of up-beat stories about economic advancement. The point the Dalai Lama has made is that the economic inflow of money to Tibet is nowhere like the outflow through the resources, the forests, the mines, the hydro-electricity that is being drained out of Tibet. But all that aside, we, as parliamentarians, have an obligation to at least know about Tibet. It is the world's biggest military-occupied country and, extraordinarily, it is occupied by a communist regime. It is the West that succours the communist regime in Beijing and ignores the theistic and now democratically elected in-exile regime of the Tibetans.

I spoke to the Chinese ambassador yesterday, and I thank him for his visit because we had a good exchange. He used the fact that countries around the world do not oppose the Chinese occupation of Tibet and, in fact, recognise that Tibet is part of China, but that is not the case.

As I said to the ambassador, the independence or otherwise of Tibet is in the hearts of the Tibetans. I laud the extraordinary bravery of those young people who, seeing a westerner standing in a temple or in a street in Lhasa, spoke to me in their halting English and told me consistently two things: we want our country's freedom and we want the Dalai Lama to return to Lhasa.

I have asked the ambassador whether he would arrange for a trip back to Tibet for me to see the country through the eyes of China. That is not a difficult thing because nearly every other MP who goes to Tibet must fulfil certain obligations, which involve China being the tour guide. I hope that opportunity arises because I do not seek, and have not sought, to be one eyed about this. I have to report to the Senate that I find the plight of the Tibetans an extraordinary blot on the civilised thinking and actions of the global community at the end of this century.

I went to Nepal and India and visited refugee camps and was amazed to find, among other things, that the flow of refugees south over the Himalayas is increasing. It will be up to 4,000 this year. These people, who are supposed to love the motherland of China but are walking out on it from their own country, do not do so at the drop of a hat. They are not allowed passports. So much for citizenship of China. They cannot leave with a valid passport.

When they do go to Nepal they choose winter, because that is when the raging rivers coming down out of the Himalayas are frozen and they can walk across them. There are three major passes they use to cross the Himalayas; one is near Mount Everest. They climb through the snows in winter. I ran into a young man in Kathmandu who is now learning how to paint traditional Tibetan art—something he did not have access to in his own country—and he lost both his legs to frostbite. He was caught in a blizzard in the pass. His four companions lost their lives. Yet the government in this country does not recognise people from Tibet as refugees because that might upset Beijing.

I saw in Nepal and India the hundreds of children who are being smuggled out of Tibet. Their parents want them to have a Tibetan education; indeed, they want them to have some form of education. Time and again I ran into young girls, 16 and 17, who had never been to school in Tibet. Why not? Among other reasons, one has to pay a fee to go to school—up-front fees in a communist country, if you do not mind! Those who cannot pay the fees are the poorest. Who are the poorest in their own country? It is the Tibetans. Who comes last on the opportunity list? I guess it is the girls. But to see the happiness of these youngsters, having got out of the country, is extraordinary, because at last they have an opportunity in life, and their parents are having them smuggled out.

One 16-year-old girl said, `I was with my brothers and two monks came along and said, "Go and go now." I did. I did not even have time to go home and tell my mum and dad and here I am, I do not know what mum and dad think. I do not know whether they know I am here, but I am here now to get my Tibetan education.' She had to decide whether she would go into the usual education stream, or become a nun herself. She has the opportunity to do that now. She effectively had no such opportunity and no schooling under the Chinese regime. There are thousands of such youngsters in Nepal and India.

A word needs to be said, because there have been tough times in the past, for the growing attitude of assistance by the Nepali government, as well as by the Indian government in these circumstances. I was able, through the good offices of our ambassador in Kathmandu, to meet the Nepali Minister for Home Affairs to try to get the thousands of Tibetans in Nepal travel documents, so they can go to countries like Germany and Britain—travel documents like those afforded to Tibetan refugees in India. He gave me a good hearing. This is good for business for Nepal as well, because the Tibetans make carpets and export them to the West, but the business people in Nepal have great difficulty getting out to make the deals which will allow this industry to bring an income to the Tibetan community.

Finally, Tibet will be an item on the agenda while I am in this parliament. I use this opportunity to ask the government, our government, to play a much more prominent role in the interests of Tibet and Tibetans and their thirst for freedom in the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —There is a certain sense of occasion in speaking on a matter of importance in the national parliament's final sitting week of the twentieth century—in fact, the final sitting week of the millennium. The cusp of the new millennium is about as auspicious an occasion as you could want to reflect on our nation's achievements of the past and the challenges of the future. It has been a momentous century for this nation, commencing with the birth of federation. It has seen us commit our troops during two world wars and in other regional conflicts, including Korea, Vietnam and the Persian Gulf.

speech.para: Our troops have defended our freedoms and defended those unable to help themselves, such as in the current deployment of Australian troops in East Timor. These encounters have undeniably defined our national identity. We are proud of the Anzac spirit, a spirit characterised by bravery, loyalty and mateship. This is the spirit by which Australian men and women have shed their blood to protect the country they love—Australia—and their fellow Australians. It is a spirit which saw a lone soldier, Private Simpson, and his donkey braving enemy fire to rescue wounded mates in that fateful Gallipoli landing. There is also the great sporting tradition that has developed over the years. Over the past century, Australia has produced superb sports men and women, and I am sure that this prowess will be evident in the year 2000 at the Sydney Olympic Games and the Paralympic Games.

Australia has also been shaped this century by the patterns of migration that have come to our shores. Australia has been a great migrant nation, advantaged by the intake of skill, labour and social diversity. Whether in the days of the gold rushes or Queensland cane growing, or our more recent past in the 1950s that gave us the mighty Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme, migration has shaped our multicultural character. The question, however, remains as to what level of immigration is in the national interest. Our population is unlikely to grow sufficiently without immigration to take advantage of global and regional opportunities, nor will it be conducive to maintaining our national security. We do need to look to a pattern of migration over the next decades that will foster properly thought-out national goals.

However, perhaps the most enduring symbol of our nation is the Australian bush. For more than 150 years, Australia has ridden on the sheep's back. The bush has provided Australia with a wealth of verse, culture, inventions and history. Bush legends have permeated Australia's identity and Australians relate to these whether they are based in the city or the outback. The bush legend and notions of the bushie with his swag are part of Australia's psyche. It is part of what Australia is today. The bush spirit is the Australian spirit.

Australia has reached the end of this century in good shape. We can be justifiably proud of our secure democracy, tolerant society and vibrant economy. But along with our prosperity and progress is the growing realisation that not all Australians have shared equally in this good fortune. As a nation, perhaps the greatest challenge we face is to bridge the gap between those who prosper and those who have missed out. Nowhere is this need more pressing than in parts of rural and regional Australia.

I have spoken often this year on issues relating to rural and regional Australia in this chamber. The themes have varied from youth unemployment to regional development and living standards in rural and regional Australia, policy positions that impact on the bush such as national competition policy, and the impact of agencies seemingly beyond the control of government such as the World Trade Organisation. These speeches have reflected journeys that I have taken within my home state of New South Wales to go to the people most affected and discuss the issues with them.

This past decade has seen the divide between the city and the bush widen to a chasm. Not only is it a divide between city and country, but also between inland and coastal areas, between the sun belt and the rural belt and between large and small regional centres. In short, it is between those who have prospered and those who have missed out on the benefits of massive technological change and deregulation.

The impact on the bush has been characterised by political protest and socioeconomic dislocation. The trend for Australia to become two nations flies in the face of our egalitarian spirit. It is simply unAustralian to tolerate the alienation of some Australians from others. The volatility of rural and regional Australia is deeply troubling. It has exercised a great deal of my time and attention this year in my `Senate Goes Bush' series of visits to rural and regional Australia. These visits reflect my belief that we do need to go bush if we are to really know the hardships and, indeed, the strengths of rural and regional Australia and if we are to have any hope of reconnecting with country Australia.

In each place I visited it was clear that the people of rural and regional Australia have been doing it tough. As recent election results attest, they also feel disillusioned and disaffected with the political processes that impact upon their daily lives. Parts of rural and regional Australia have been hurting. Not only have the regions been fighting drought and shifts in population, but the regions face trying to overcome the tyranny of distance when accessing services that those in the city take for granted.

However, it has become abundantly clear to me that rural and regional Australia does have the capacity to regenerate itself so long as the conditions are right. Part of the reconnecting process is that the government is addressing the sectoral needs of regional Australia. A suite of programs is designed to turn around the geographical disadvantage in this vast land. There are no quick fixes, but sustained effort, understanding and increased expenditure are helping to address the balance.

Bridging the gap between the haves and the have-nots may well be the most important policy challenge we face. Any regeneration and development of rural and regional Australia must also grapple with the kind of framework that best suits the purpose. Despite the splendid initiative of the Regional Summit and our desire to recreate the securities of the past, I suspect that we have not yet asked ourselves what rural and regional communities of the future will look like. What indeed is our big picture?

In a recent ABC Country Viewpoint broadcast, the following questions were asked: does the big picture envisage a network of regional centres that are just smaller versions of our state capital cities or does the big picture envisage a network of services that are virtual and accessed only through the Internet? Does the big picture envisage millions of hectares of plantations providing carbon credits for multinational corporations? Does the big picture include the old vision of a food bowl for the rest of the world? Whatever policy mix is used, an issue for the government is to identify and promote strategic investment in the future of the nation that will see the growth of prosperous, well-serviced regions.

There is a political divide, of course, on how to achieve this. Experience has demonstrated that a top-down attempt to establish major regional centres is unlikely to succeed unless there is significant local leadership and community support. This approach also ignores the need of those in smaller communities who are unable, because of geographic isolation, to access the services of major centres. An enduring impression that I have taken away from the Senate Goes Bush visits is that people of rural and regional Australia do not want hand-outs; what they want is a hand up. This means that there is a leadership role for government to assist local communities to assist themselves, to identify their strengths and weaknesses and, indeed, to find their own way forward.

It is up to all of us in government, in the private sector, in unions, in regional development organisations and local councils to find a way for regional communities to identify and harness their potential. The government's proposal as part of the rural summit to get some help from the big end of town, colloquially speaking, in setting up a rural trust is a significant step in bridging the gap between the haves and the have-nots. More importantly, it recognises the moral obligation we have to include rural and regional Australia in the nation's prosperity. If we fail to do this, we diminish our achievement as a successful nation.

Last week, the Prime Minister chaired the first meeting of the government's business and community initiative to promote the notion of a social coalition. It brings together the resources of the government, the private sector, individuals and the Australian business community. Clearly, an integrated approach will maximise our chances for rural and regional renewal. It will also be necessary, I suggest, to carefully consider the impact of decisions imposed on Australia by global organisations such as the WTO.

No-one will deny that trade is the lifeblood of this country and we need to keep our strategy under review. We cannot afford to drop the ball on this issue in Australia. As a country that overwhelmingly relies on exports for our survival, we must continue our participation in the WTO, but we must also keep our strategy in doing this under close scrutiny.

The clear lesson from the Seattle round is that people affected by WTO decisions want to have a say in matters that affect them. The protests that we all saw on our televisions and read about in newspapers were not as much about global free trade, I suggest, but rather the way in which this is pursued by the WTO, seemingly without regard to the impact on a local community. The dispute settlement rules are opaque and in need of reform. It is little wonder that those on the receiving end of adverse decisions are often puzzled by and invariably angry with decisions they do not understand. The decision against Australia on the importation of uncooked salmon products is simply a case in point.

Notwithstanding the matters that I have mentioned today in this matter of public interest debate, I must say that I am buoyed by the signs of regeneration in rural and regional Australia and confident that the innate decency of our fellow Australians will see us face the new millennium with both hope and resolve to meet these challenges. I would like to take this opportunity to wish all of my colleagues, the clerks, the Senate staff and Hansard, who serve us with such distinction throughout the year, the very best Christmas and a New Year filled with promise.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in this debate on matters of public interest to raise the need for an Aboriginal languages interpreter service in the Northern Territory. In these days of modern travel it is not unusual for many of us to find ourselves in countries around the globe, for business or pleasure, where English is not the national language. Luckily for those of us who speak English, it has become the most widely spoken language in the world and in most places it is relatively easy to find someone who speaks some English. However, most of us have found ourselves at one time or another in a situation where we do not speak the local language and nobody seems to speak a language that we can understand. Some of us may have even found ourselves in a situation where we have had to deal with government bureaucracies in those countries or seek medical treatment from a local doctor or hospital or even have had to deal with police or perhaps a local court—environments where nobody seems to speak a language we can understand and the proceedings are not understood by us. It is a frightening and disorienting experience, not being able to understand what is being said and being unable to make yourself understood.

speech.para: For a large percentage of Aboriginal Territorians—and I am sure elsewhere in Australia where we find indigenous Australians from a traditional background—the problems of a lack of understanding in the court system, the health system or government bureaucracies is a regular occurrence, often with dire consequences. Perhaps it is important to place some statistics on the record so we have a picture of what we are dealing with here.

Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory make up about 27 per cent of the population. Of these people it is estimated that about 75 per cent speak an indigenous language, or languages even, and have a very poor or limited understanding of English. In 1997-98, Aboriginal people made up 70 per cent of people who fronted the Northern Territory's court system. In the same period Aboriginal people made up more than 50 per cent of patients in the Northern Territory's hospital system. In contrast, non-English speaking background Territorians—those from overseas non-English speaking countries—made up only 8 per cent of the Northern Territory's population. However, when dealing with the judiciary, the health system or government bureaucracies, NESB Territorians have 24-hour access to free government provided interpreter services. If you are Chinese, you can; if you are Laotian, you can; if you are Greek or Spanish you can. Off the top of my head I think about 150 languages are catered for. That is only fair. Most reasonable people would consider that it is only fair that non-English speakers have access to interpreter services.

However, if you happen to be an indigenous Australian in the Northern Territory with no or limited English, the situation is vastly different. Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory are not automatically provided with interpreter services to help with language difficulties in accessing any community services. Of particular concern is the lack of Aboriginal interpreter services to allow them to access health and legal services. It is outrageous but true.

Over 20 years ago Aboriginal linguist Gloria Brennan wrote a report investigating the need for an Aboriginal interpreting service, concluding there was a real and urgent need for such a service. Finally, 18 years later, an Aboriginal languages interpreter service was trialled in the Top End over a six-month period. Focusing predominantly on health and legal services, the trial addressed the following four key issues: whether there existed a need for such a service; the feasibility of establishing a permanent service; the most effective means by which a service might run; and how much it was likely to cost. The report, titled Executive Summary Northern Territory Aboriginal Languages Interpreter Service Trial Evaluation Report, was circulated to members of a working party looking at Aboriginal interpreter services and other proponents of Aboriginal interpreter services throughout Darwin.

The findings of the draft report were very clear. It highlighted the need for an Aboriginal service and it recommended that it be administered through the existing Northern Territory Interpreter and Translator Service (NTITS), which would be both cost effective and consistent with the government's position on the mainstreaming of service delivery to Aboriginal people.

In May 1998 a final report was published by the Northern Territory Attorney-General's Department, titled Trial Aboriginal Languages Interpreter Service—Evaluation Report. However, the integrity of the published report has been questioned by members of the working group and proponents of an interpreter service. What happened has been explained by a member of that working group, Mr Russell Goldflam. He said:

The draft report, which clearly recommended the establishment of the nation's first Aboriginal interpreter service, never saw the light of day and was replaced by a watered-down version several months later, which was prepared and published without involvement of members of the Working Group.

Interestingly enough, even though they were invited to do so, the Northern Territory Attorney-General's Department did not address this matter as part of the Northern Territory government's submission to the inquiry into the provision of an interpreter service in Aboriginal languages which was conducted by the Northern Territory government under the auspices of the then NT Anti-Discrimination Commissioner, Dawn Lawrie.

In February this year, Dawn Lawrie, who was the then NT Anti-Discrimination Commissioner, began a public inquiry into the provision of interpreter services in Aboriginal languages. It attracted wide public interest with submissions received from the government, the judiciary, the legal, health and community service providers. Handing down her report some five months later, after considering nearly 100 written and oral submissions, Ms Lawrie concluded that:
The Northern Territory Government should establish an Aboriginal interpreter service and that the establishment of the service should be given the highest priority.

Not only that, Ms Lawrie stated that the lack of Aboriginal interpreter services in the Northern Territory is discriminatory, contravening both the federal Racial Discrimination Act of 1995 and also the Northern Territory's own Anti-Discrimination Act of 1992.

Over the years the Northern Territory government's response has been that an Aboriginal interpreter service would be too expensive. If they are not prepared to accept the argument of justice and equity in providing such a service, they should consider the economic arguments in favour of an Aboriginal interpreter service. Clearly the provision of properly trained legal and medical interpreters would save far more than the cost of such a service by reducing court delays, retrials and incorrect diagnosis and/or treatment in our hospitals.

A study by Dr Peter Collins for the Northern Territory's Office of Aboriginal Development in 1995 in fact pointed out that the introduction of an Aboriginal interpreter service would be very cost effective. In the health sector a properly funded interpreter service will lessen the potential for claims against medical negligence, misdiagnosis, readmissions and so on. In the legal setting the savings for less court and police time would be enormous. The lack of an Aboriginal interpreter service is placing enormous pressure on our court systems in the Northern Territory.

Not long after Dawn Lawrie's report was released the federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Herron, was reported as saying that Aboriginal people should take some responsibility for such a service and that ATSIC should provide the funds for it. The minister's comments say a lot about his support for the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory and the services they need. As the Reverend Jim Downing succinctly stated in response to Senator Heron's comments later in a letter to the Northern Territory News:

Has he . . . or any other Government Minister suggested that the Turks, Greeks, Italians, Vietnamese, and all the other racial groups provided with a 24 hours interpreter service should pay for their service? No it is the sort of service a government should provide.

At this point I repeat an earlier point I made: that is, in the Northern Territory there is full-time free interpreter service available to people from non-English speaking backgrounds, but not if you are Aboriginal.

A recent incident, however, which received much media attention, highlights what can happen and has happened due to the lack of an Aboriginal interpreter service. Recently at the Royal Darwin Hospital a young Aboriginal woman was sterilised without understanding that the procedure was permanent. Traditionally the Northern Territory government has relied on either family members or friends who may speak English to translate between patients and staff. However, they are not trained interpreters. There is no guarantee that they may be around when needed, there are cultural constraints on them in explaining certain matters, and they do not necessarily understand the procedures involved. The chief minister's response to the media attention given to this revelation of the young woman being sterilised without her consent was that he rejected the need for an Aboriginal interpreter service and said:
to my mind (that) is akin to providing a wheelchair for someone who should be able to walk.

Speaking in parliament about translators, he went on to say that it was a disgrace that Aborigines still needed them. His comments would almost be laughable if they did not reflect his obvious lack of humanity, his lack of understanding of the cultural principals involved and his lack of understanding of the principals of justice in our legal and health system.

While Mr Burke has previously acknowledged there was a need for an Aboriginal interpreter service, he said it should be paid for by federal government funding. Obviously he does not consider the introduction of an Aboriginal interpreter service a high priority for his government. It is somewhat ironic really. On the one hand, he considers himself to be the great helmsman steering the North ern Territory towards the holy grail of statehood, yet he is not prepared for the Territory to meet its responsibilities regarding the equal treatment of Territorians. Last week the former Anti-Discrimination Commissioner, Dawn Lawrie, in responding to these comments by the Chief Minister, said what a lot of people in the Northern Territory are becoming increasingly inclined to think. She said, `Denis Burke is a national disgrace', and she is right.

I conclude my remarks by saying that the debate over the introduction of an Aboriginal interpreter service is not about whether people should speak English. It is about what the reality is now and what impact it is having on many Territorians. This is something Denis Burke does not want to seem to grasp; that is, that a large percentage of Territorians are being discriminated against. They are denied a basic service that is offered to all other non-English speaking Territorians.

Aboriginal Territorians need an Aboriginal interpreter service and they need it now. Hopefully in the future, non-English speaking Aboriginal people will be as fluent in English as they are in their own languages, and it would be an advantage to them if they were. But at the moment that is not the case, and it needs to be addressed. There is simply no excuse for the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory not to introduce an Aboriginal interpreter service immediately. He is directly responsible for the consequences of not doing so.

I want to mention the names of some people involved in legal and health issues in the Territory. They include the Supreme Court Judge, the Hon. Justice Dean Mildren; the Director of Public Prosecutions, Rex Wild QC; the recently retired Hon. Justice William Kearney; the Director of Legal Aid, Richard Coates; the Director of the North Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service, Gordon Renouf; the Director of Anglicare, Peter Fisher; Dr Ilona DeBella, from the Royal Darwin Hospital; Jackie Vincent, who is the chairperson of the Katherine Aboriginal Language Centre; and Dr Sam Heard. The list goes on and on.

Why have I mentioned them? Because they all support the introduction of an Aboriginal interpreter service. Why is it that the leaders in the Aboriginal legal and health areas can see what is so blindly obvious, but the Chief Minister, Denis Burke, will not allow the Northern Territory to meet its responsibilities by establishing immediately such a service? I firmly believe that the Chief Minister, Denis Burke, should be held personally accountable for what happens as a result of the lack of an Aboriginal interpreter service in the Northern Territory.
