subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Does the Assistant Treasurer recall his own answer yesterday when he said:

question.para: Charities can structure their activities to take account of individual fundraising efforts, if that is the way they wish to go. Charities will undoubtedly take every advantage they can under the law, as the law is written, and that is what we would expect them to do.

If the government really wanted to help charities why are they not just taken out of the punitive GST net instead of encouraging them to do everything they can under the law to avoid the Howard-Lees GST? Wasn't one of the government's main claims for introducing the GST that nobody could escape paying their fair share? Isn't the government now giving the green light to individuals and businesses who under the law may be able to avoid or minimise paying the GST?

talk.start.para: —What an astonishing question from Senator Murphy—a truly astonishing question. All the Labor Party complaints over the last week or so have been that a GST is being imposed on aspects of charitable works. That has been your complaint over the last week. Now Senator Murphy is worried that charities are going to avoid the GST. Get real! Where is the Labor Party coming from on any issue? It beats me. Because you do not believe in anything you flip-flop on everything and one day you argue on one side of the street—
—Senator, address your remarks to the chair, not across the chamber.

—Thank you, Madam President. The trouble is, as I was saying, that if you do not believe in anything, if you do not stand for anything, if you do not know where you stand on an issue, you run contradictory lines, which we have just seen from Senator Shayne Murphy. We are bringing in a very fair tax system which will be of benefit to charities, of benefit to large and small business, of benefit to taxpayers, of benefit to families and, particularly, of benefit to those on pensions and benefits. We have a tax reform program; we want to make sure Australia has a tax system which will take us into the new millennium and which is fairer and more equitable and which will better enable Australia to compete on world markets—in other words, a tax system which is the world's best practice.

answer.para: You ask such a question because you have no philosophy, you have no views, you have no policies. I ask the Labor Party to work out with their colleagues whether they are worried about the GST affecting charities or are they worried about charities escaping the GST. Just get your lines straight. It shows the appalling leadership the Australian Labor Party has both in the other chamber and in this chamber that you cannot get your lines straight on this particular issue.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. One thing we have worked out on this side is that this minister does not and cannot answer questions. But the Assistant Treasurer might be able to answer this supplementary. In regard to charities being able to `structure their activities to take account of individual fundraising efforts', can the minister outline exactly what restructuring charities will be able to do to avoid the Howard-Lees GST and at what further cost to the charities? For example, will charities now have to set up ABC Charities (Lamington Drive) Inc., followed by ABC Charities (Gala Evening) Inc. and maybe even ABC Charities (Money for GST Compliance Costs) Inc. in order to remain under the GST threshold?

—It goes from bad to worse with you, Senator Murphy. You are good at fly-fishing—no-one in this chamber argues that. You are probably the champion fly-fisher, Senator. But, frankly, this question? We are providing flexibility to charities—that is what we are doing. This means that pie drives, lamington drives, cake stalls, Christmas cake sales and all of those sorts of things will not come into the system unless the particular charity has a turnover on those projects of over $100,000. It is perfectly straightforward. Will charities want to restructure? Charities will obviously make a choice. Charities will work out what suits the particular charity. This is exactly what charities wanted. It might not be what Shayne Murphy wants, but this is what charities wanted and we have delivered to them in spadefuls.
—My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald.
—Macca! Macca!
—Order! That sort of behaviour and shouting is absolutely unintelligible and unintelligent.

—I can only put it down to end of year exuberance, Madam President. The minister will recall that almost exactly 12 months ago he said that `1999 will be the year of regional Australia'. Will the minister inform the Senate how successful the partnership has been between the federal government and rural and regional Australia, and in particular what programs will have continuing benefit for regional Australians in 2000 and beyond?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lightfoot for the question and for his ongoing interest in rural and regional Australia. Certainly 12 months ago I did nominate 1999 as the year for regional Australia, and I am pleased to say that the Howard government has focused Australia's attention on rural and regional Australia in that time. I am proud to have been one of the two ministers appointed to look after the interests of rural and regional Australia, in the regional services area. My colleagues Senator Troeth, Mr Truss, Mr Tuckey and I have concentrated on things that will help regional Australia.

answer.para: We have acknowledged that a lot of good things have happened in rural and regional Australia but that progress has not been even across the board. We are aware that there are patches of rural and regional Australia which need further attention. But we have focused the attention on rural and regional Australia. In fact, most of Australia now understands that we have to look more closely at rural and regional Australia. Business, state governments and the federal government do—it seems all do except the Australian Labor Party. They have absolutely no policies on regional Australia. They have done no work towards those policies. All they have done when talking about rural and regional Australia is carp and criticise the good things that we have done.

Madam President, you will remember that in the last 12 months the Labor Party appointed someone who was going to be the saviour of the bush, a high profile Labor person—well, she had been for a little while—who was going to really fix regional Australia from the Labor Party point of view. What happened? She was sacked during the year because she could not help rural and regional Australia. She was sacked from that shadow portfolio and replaced by a regional spokesman who lives in the centre of Melbourne and who has said on two occasions recently that he understands the problems of rural and regional Australia because the same problems are happening in his electorate in inner city Melbourne.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. It goes to relevance. I understood the minister got a dorothy dixer from his own side about how well this government was treating rural and regional Australia. We have listened to him for some time but we have not heard anything. We really would like to know just what you are doing for rural and regional Australia rather than commenting on what other people in other parties may or may not be doing. It would be useful for us if the minister could inform us exactly what the government is doing.
—There is no point of order.
—I can understand why the Labor Party try to stop me telling them what we have done for rural and regional Australia and what they have not done.

answer.para: More specifically, we have cut costs to rural and regional Australia. We have done that by removing some 23c a litre on fuel for trucks that work in rural and regional Australia. We have got rid of the wholesale sales tax, that debilitating Labor tax. We have removed $4 billion from export costs. We have removed $10 billion from costs of small business. We have removed $7,500 on average from the costs of every farmer. And every one of those initiatives was opposed by the Labor Party.

We have increased telecommunications to the bush: $464 million into the bush—opposed by the Labor Party. We held a regional summit which focused on rural and regional Australia. What did the Labor Party do? They attended, said a word saying it was not a bad idea, and then nitpicked on costs, nitpicked on the little things, criticised and carped on the little things. We have had the RTC program, the rural transaction centres, $70 million putting banking transaction centres back into the bush—opposed by Labor. They did not want to give us the $70 million to do it. It was opposed by Labor all the way through. The Natural Heritage Trust, $1½ billion, most of which goes into rural and regional Australia—opposed by the Labor Party and criticised project by project. We have done a lot, and in the future we intend to carry on those programs. I personally intend to continue my visits to rural and regional Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister continue to outline those initiatives that will have great bearing on rural and regional Australia in the next millennium?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Again I thank Senator Lightfoot. We want to continue on the initiatives we have made in the health area with the opening of the James Cook University Medical School to put more doctors into rural and regional Australia. We want to spend the money we have allocated to help get pharmacists, doctors and allied health professionals into rural and regional Australia. I and most of my colleagues spend a lot of time in country Australia. Last year I spent 61 days in rural and regional Australia, 62 days with local governments, 24 days in the territories and 45 days in my offices in rural and regional Australia, meeting all the time, listening and understanding, as my colleagues do. The Labor Party do none of that, because their spokesman lives in Melbourne and stays there. Next year we hope to open more RTCs, more telecommunications. We are having the Northern Australia Forum to focus on that part of regional Australia. And so it goes on. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Animal Sponsorships

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister confirm that, under the Howard-Lees GST, Sydney's Taronga Zoo will have to send 10 per cent of the moneys raised through their animal sponsorship program to the federal government, as confirmed by an ATO ruling? Is it fair that, although corporate donors may get a GST input credit, the $300,000 in sponsorship from the general public, including the children who get a certificate of appreciation for sponsoring animals like Chester the white tiger, will have the 10 per cent GST skimmed off for the government's coffers? Isn't the government ashamed that it is slashing the value of kids' sponsorships of Taronga's animals from $300,000 by a 10 per cent tax?

question.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise is unacceptable by any standards and I do not think that senators appreciate the way behaviour is viewed by writers and phone callers to the parliament.

—Thank you, Madam President, and thank you, Senator Conroy, for the question. I would have to say there was a trifle of overacting there, Senator Conroy, in line with your usual form. This is totally in line with the sort of nitpicking questions that we receive from the Labor Party. Very relevant information, I believe, to the issues which have been raised by Senator Conroy in relation to the impact of the goods and services tax on charities came this morning from none other than the Salvation Army. I think it may be of interest to hear what the Salvation Army said. The Salvation Army said it is now comfortable with the GST. It said:

answer.para: With the compensation that has been provided by the government, we have signed off on it.—
We believe that the government is providing—

talk.start.para: —Senator Evans, abide by the standing orders.
—It said:

answer.para: We believe that the government is providing adequate compensation, that in fact the government is providing funding for ongoing education.

So we have bodies like the Salvation Army really taking issue with the sorts of complaints that the Labor Party is making. Basically what we are seeing is an attempt by the Labor Party to scare people to bring about some fear and concern where there is no need for fear and concern.

Sponsorship arrangements made by a GST registered charity will generally be subject to GST. This is because sponsorships are effectively payments in return for a service of advertising or other benefits. However, Senator, because a sponsorship transaction will typically take place between two registered entities, the impact of the GST will net out. You raised the case of where an entity, I understand, is input taxed.

talk.start.para: —Children's sponsorships!

—You raised the case of corporate sponsorship and even though, in the case of input taxed financial organisations, they will be unable to claim an input tax credit in respect of sponsorships undertaken, all other input taxed financial organisations will be in a similar position. Senator, we are bringing in a new tax system—
—You don't know, do you?
—Senator, I just—
—Senator Kemp, ignore the interjections.

—Senator, I have outlined the general issues in relation to corporate sponsorship. If you are speaking about a membership, we can go through that for you, but the truth of the matter, Senator, is that what is going to happen is that we are going to bring in a tax system which will be delivering real rises in disposable incomes for Australian families. They will be far better off under our system than under the system that the Labor Party currently supports. Who knows what in the future the Labor Party will support? We are very confident that individuals and families will certainly be better off as a result of our system.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, won't the application of GST to sponsorships like this undermine community support for making gifts to organisations like Taronga Zoo, with the knowledge that the government is going to get a 10 per cent cut of the action?

—If you are speaking about a specific membership or a specific issue, we will of course provide advice on that. But, if you are speaking about the general issue of sponsorship, Senator, the fact of the matter is that we believe that, as a result of the measures that we have brought in, bodies like the zoo will certainly not suffer from our system and we believe they will in fact benefit.

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Australians are vitally concerned about drugs, crime and access to justice. Will the minister inform the Senate of initiatives and achievements in the Attorney-General's and Justice and Customs portfolios?

—I thank Senator Coonan for the question. It is quite appropriate, as we approach the end of the year, to look on the achievements in each portfolio. The first that I would nominate in this portfolio is the contribution the AFP made in East Timor. They were the first people there. There are 40 that are still there. They gave extremely meritorious service and I would particularly like to mention Alan Mills, a retired AFP Assistant Commissioner who gave distinguished service as the UNAMET commander in East Timor. That I would single out as a great achievement for the Federal Police this year.

answer.para: The Federal Police and the NCA are of course now properly resourced. They have had increased money, as I was able to mention yesterday, under the Tough on Drugs initiatives. They have had record seizures of heroin, cocaine and amphetamines. We have had the arrests of major international fugitives and, most importantly for the man and the woman in the street, they have been very successful—through the Swordfish reference—in catching up with tax cheats, something that the people opposite when they were in government never did.

The next achievement that I would like to mention is that of CrimTrac, an extremely overdue need to put together law enforcement information from all the state police services, and we are starting with a fingerprint system that was allowed—over 13 years under Labor—to fall into absolute disrepair to the point that it was effectively useless.

We have given Customs the resources and powers to do the job, and all we hear from the other side is, `Why don't you peel a bit off, establish a new authority and call it a coastguard?' In contrast to that, the Prime Minister's task force has put $124 million of new money in, including new Dash 8 aircraft, a night capable helicopter and a national surveillance centre. In relation to law reform, this government has initiated and passed sex slavery legislation. It is very important for Australia to be taking the lead in this area to demonstrate that we will not put up with trafficking, especially in women, for use as sex slaves. We have passed legislation in relation to foreign bribery so that our companies when competing overseas compete on quality and price and not on whether they have got money to bribe the person they are getting the contract from. We have introduced theft, fraud and bribery legislation, which is a part of major criminal law reform. We have had a report done by the Australian Law Reform Commission on the confiscation of proceeds of crime, and we will be acting on that report early next year. Crime prevention under this government is getting the money and the attention it deserves.

There is a whole range of achievements. There is one thing that this parliament could have achieved, not just for itself but for all Australians. But, sadly, because of people opposite, it is not going to happen. Sports drugs is one area in which we could have seen a very exciting achievement by this parliament. Because we have the Sydney Olympics next year, it is important that Australia demonstrates we want a clean Olympics and that we show what we are prepared to do towards that. Customs has legislation at hand to increase the penalties on people who import performance enhancing drugs, to turn them into middle level narcotic penalties. The Democrats are prepared to support us, Senator Harradine is prepared to support us, One Nation are prepared to support us. We could pass this legislation before Christmas and have an effective regime leading up to the Olympics. What does Labor say? `Send it off to a committee.' They have not even thought about it. Kate Lundy is sitting there looking down.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Lundy.

—The reason Senator Lundy is looking down is she is responsible for sports matters and has not done anything about it. They have not got a policy. That is why they have to send it off to a committee—to think about it. That is why it will be delayed. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Can the Assistant Treasurer inform the Senate whether the ladies' committee of Sydney's Royal North Shore Hospital will have to pay GST on their sales of biscuits, cakes, jams and pickles, which raised $164,000 last year for the hospital to purchase essential medical equipment? Can the minister also confirm advice the ladies' committee has received from a member of the Charities Consultative Committee that, while it would probably be liable for a GST on sales, this charity would not be able to get back some of its GST paid on materials bought by the volunteers? Why is the Howard government insisting on forcing this charity and thousands more like it to be surrogate tax collectors?

—Senator, I do not know whether you have tuned into the debate in recent days, but we have had an extensive discussion on cakes stalls. In fact, I think we have heard the word `lamington' more in this chamber in the last couple of days than we have heard in the last 50 years. The situation is this: the charities will decide how they structure their activities. Some charities will want to register for the GST, and some will want to remain outside the system. That is their choice. If they believe that they want to be part of the system—and many will—they will be able to claim the input tax credits. If they do not wish to be part of the system, then they can have the option, as the Treasurer has so lucidly outlined, to structure their activities.

answer.para: Let me quote what the Treasurer said—I thought it was a pretty good quote, and I think we can afford to share it with you again in this chamber. He was referring to a charity:
We are going to make it unequivocally clear in the legislation that unless you are a charity that has a turnover of $100,000, you do not come into the system.

That is what it means: pie drives, lamington cake stalls, Christmas cakes and all those sorts of things will not come into the system unless they have a turnover on those projects of over $100,000. He went on to say, `Well, they can structure their affairs so they can take advantage of it on an individual fundraising activity.' So, if a charity wants to stay outside the system, it is up to it how it structures its activities. Unless the project is going over $100,000, they can stay outside the system. The point I am making to you is simply this: that particular charity or group will make a decision as to whether they want to remain outside the GST system, in which case they will not be able to claim their input tax credits, or whether they want to become part of the system, in which case they will be able to. So we are providing that flexibility to charities.

This is what charities want. When they came to see us, charities wanted to have flexibility in this area. I have to tell you that a lot of people are getting very fed up with the Labor Party's attitude on this. I quoted to you in my previous answer what the Salvation Army said in an interview with Pat Daly. I think they summed it up very well indeed. There was also an interview with Richard Menteith of the Wesley Mission. This shows how outside the ball game the Labor Party are at the moment. This is what Wesley Mission says:
Wesley Mission has always seen the GST as a significant improvement on the other tax paradigms and regimes that we have had in previous years.

talk.start.para: —Cash for comment!

—I know it hurts, Senator Conroy—after all the effort of the scare campaign, after all the attempts by the Labor Party; a party without policies, a party without any views on how we should reform Australia.
—Order! Minister, the time has concluded.
—Madam President, if I could have a supplementary, I have got a few more quotes from Wesley City Mission to share.

—I advise the minister that the information I was asking him was actually provided by the Charities Consultative Committee. As a supplementary question I ask: is the government seriously asking this charity and thousands more like it to restructure themselves to avoid the complexity and paperwork imposed on all charities by the Howard-Lees GST? Should this charity be setting up separate entities, like the North Shore Ladies Committee (Cakes) Unit, the North Shore Ladies Committee (Jams) Unit and the North Shore Ladies Committee (Pickles) Unit? Doesn't this just impose a different set of complexities and paperwork on this charity? Just how is the government going to get itself out of this pickle of its own making?
—Rosemary Crowley—
—Senator Crowley, please, Senator.
—Senator Crowley has done a Shayne Murphy—
—Senator, you should refer to senators correctly.

—Senator Crowley is worried that charities will be in the system and Senator Crowley is worried that charities will be out of the system. One of the many good things in this package is that, with the structuring arrangements we have announced, a lot of charities will find it very convenient to take advantage of those arrangements. There are advantages in being in the system, and some charities may see their advantages in being out of the system. It is their choice.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Air Fares

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Ian Macdonald, representing the Minister for Transport. It relates to the proposal by Virgin Airlines to concentrate its Australian operations on the main intercapital trunk routes. Given the existing two domestic airlines operate a national network of services that includes many low density, regional services, what assurances can the senator give the residents of rural and regional Australia that the likely downward pressure on fares charged by the incumbent airlines on trunk routes through Virgin's intended cherry picking strategy does not lead to upward pressures on the less competitive regional routes as a result of the reduced capacity of Ansett and Qantas to cross-subsidise routes?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —We as a government are confident right across the whole spectrum of government activities that competition brings a better deal for customers and brings lower prices. You start from that premise. Senator, you are raising a concern which I also raised when this matter was first mentioned. I have to emphasise that there is no evidence of any of that happening. My point in raising it—and no doubt yours—was just to let people out there know we are looking.

answer.para: When I looked at this question a year or so ago, I made a point of getting some of the company returns for the subsidiaries of Ansett and Qantas who do the rural and regional routes. The reports that I was able to get all showed that they were doing quite nicely as independent units. They are not cross-subsidised by the major trunk route carriers.

I am also aware—I have no special knowledge about this; I just use my eyes, read the paper and have a look around—that there are a number of independent players, not related to Qantas or Ansett, who quite successfully operate in rural and regional Australia. One is Flight West, a very good Queensland based airline that runs in rural and regional Queensland and out to Norfolk Island. It seems to be quite profitable, and it provides an excellent service. It does it on its own—it receives no subsidy from Ansett or Qantas. Similarly, Impulse Airlines, operating out of Newcastle, seems to operate quite successfully without any cross-subsidy.

I, like you, Senator, want to keep an eye on it. It seems to me that those magnificent services that have been provided by the rural and regional operators for those of us who live in rural and regional Australia will continue. There is nothing in anything that Virgin has done or in anything that Qantas and Ansett have said that would lead me to think there would be any diminution in the services to rural and regional Australia. Virgin will provide huge benefits for those on the major trunk routes. I like to think that people are discovering even more places up my way, like Townsville and Cairns. I think players like Virgin will follow Flight West, Qantas and Ansett in bringing services up there. That again will help with competition, and competition of course brings a better service and reduced costs.

Like you, I will keep an eye on it, but I really have no great concerns. I think the services to rural and regional Australia will continue, and I would like to compliment those currently providing those services. Although they are a little expensive and they think that those of us who live in rural and regional Australia are not quite as bulky as some of our intercapital city counterparts—the room given to us on some of the regional airliners is a little bit small—they provide a pretty good service and I congratulate them on it.

talk.start.para: —I note that the minister is keen to reassure the Senate that everything will be all right on the night. I ask as a supplementary question: does the Commonwealth intend to use the prices powers of the ACCC, or to supplement such powers as necessary, to ensure that users of regional air services do not suffer an increase in relative fare levels arising from the entry of Virgin Australia to the domestic intercapital routes?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —If Senator Greig or any other senator or citizen of Australia has any evidence that there are problems, or that there is something untoward happening that the ACCC should look at, then certainly we will refer it to the ACCC, but I do not anticipate that that will happen. The regional routes, as I have already explained, are successful in their own right. I cannot see that there is any need for it. What I can see is that competition will bring better air services right across the spectrum of the Australian airline travelling public and that things will be better. But, certainly, Senator, if you have any evidence, or if something pops up in the future that you are concerned about, by all means refer it to us. Anything untoward will be referred to the ACCC at the earliest possible time.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Gift Vouchers

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Given that this Christmas is the last Christmas that Australians can enjoy before the introduction of the Howard-Lees GST, can the minister explain what the value of services that can be purchased with a $40 post-GST gift voucher will be as opposed to the value of services that can be purchased with a $40 gift voucher this year?

—The first point is that next Christmas Australians will be even better off as a result of the government's policies. Let me tell you what people will receive next Christmas in contrast to this Christmas. Next Christmas the first thing that will come through will be the very major tax cuts. Many families will be in the order of $40 to $50 a week better off even after the imposition of the GST. That is the first thing we will see: families who are better off. We will see pensioners and those who are in receipt of benefits better off.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. The answer to this question has been going for well over one minute. I never asked anything about the so-called tax cuts which will make low income Australians worse off; I asked specifically about the value of a gift voucher in services, and what the face value of that will be this year compared with next year under a GST. Will the minister answer that question—it is a clear, precise, specific question—and not evade it by dragging in all the government propaganda about how we are all going to be better off under the GST, which no Australian believes?
—There is no point of order.
—You asked me how Australian families will be next Christmas compared with this Christmas.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. The minister has just rewritten the question. I never asked him that at all. If he would only listen to the question! I will go to it again. Given that this is the last Christmas, can the minister explain what will be the value of services that can be purchased with a $40 post-GST gift voucher as opposed to the value of services that can be purchased with a $40 gift voucher this year? That was the question.
—There is no point of order.

—The point I was trying to make to Senator Cook was that the great thing is that Australian families will be better off next Christmas. The great thing is that Australian families will be even better off. The great thing is that those in receipt of pensions and benefits will be better off. That is important, and it is something we are particularly proud of. We have special assistance for self-funded retirees. All those things are, frankly, very important measures.

answer.para: On the value of the service, the truth of the matter is that in some areas we may see prices of some services rise, and in some other areas we may see prices fall. There will be a range of changes. The truth of the matter is that you would have to specify the particular service, Senator, but we do know that Australian families will be better able to afford to buy vouchers. Some families, because they get the extra $40 or $50 a week, will be able to buy more vouchers and give more gifts. We are very proud of the measures that we are bringing in. The Labor Party opposed tax reform lock, stock and barrel.

Those people will get those vouchers next Christmas, and they will see that they will have the money in their pockets to save more or to spend more. It is something that this government is particularly proud of. Everyone looks forward to Christmas, but I have to tell you that, with this tax reform, they will be looking forward to Christmas 2000 with even more enthusiasm than this year.

The final point I make is this: what a hypocritical question, coming from Senator Cook. One of his most famous quotes—not the most famous quote, but one of his most famous—was `the Labor Party is a high taxing party'. That was a Senator Cook quote. I would type that as his third most famous quote, Madam President.

talk.start.para: —What was the first?
—No, I am not going to say what his first most famous quote was. People are well able to look it up in Hansard .

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister did not answer my question but, given his answer, it is incomplete unless he tells Australians they will be paying five per cent to seven per cent more in inflation as a consequence of the GST. My question goes back to the gift voucher. Isn't it a fact that the $40 post-GST gift voucher will be able to purchase only $36.36 worth of services next year as opposed to the full $40 face value of the gift voucher this year? Will you confirm that fact, Minister? Doesn't that mean that the Howard-Lees GST, as it will apply on gift vouchers next year, is no more than a tax on Christmas?
—Boy, is Senator Cook struggling now! I will look at one of the areas that Kate Lundy has a particular interest in.
—Senator Kemp, do not refer to a senator in that fashion.
—Senator Katherine Lundy, for some reason, wants to impose a wholesale sales tax of around 22 per cent on a lot of sporting goods. I do not know why Senator Lundy wants to do that—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My question was not about Senator Lundy and, in any event, the answer given about Senator Lundy was misleading and misrepresentative. My question was about the gift voucher. It is a simple question. If the minister is not capable of answering it, will he just sit down.
—Madam President, on the point of order—
—She's already ruled.
—I have not ruled. Some of you are making too much noise.

—I think Senator Kemp is being relevant to the question. He is talking about gifts that one might buy at Christmas time. If he wants to remain relevant, I think he should also explain to the Senate that, with a $40 gift voucher, under Liberal policies you could buy three CDs next Christmas, and if you stuck to Labor's policies on CDs and taxation you would be lucky to buy one.
—The issue is being debated and there is no point of order.
—Madam President, I have a further point of order. In recognising Senator Campbell and taking that point of order—
—It was not a taking of a point of order.
—I am aware it was not a point of order, but you did say `point of order'. You ruled it was not a point of order—
—Senator Faulkner, sit down. Senator Cook had raised a point of order—
—I am aware of that.

—Remain quiet while I finish saying what I am saying. Senator Cook took a point of order, Senator Campbell rose to speak to the point of order, and when there was sufficient silence around so that he was likely to hear, I called him to speak to the point of order that Senator Cook had made. I have not yet ruled on that point of order, and you have intervened. If you wish to speak to that, you may.
—I was trying to do that.
—You were seeking to raise another point of order, which is why I intervened.

—The point I am making is this: when a government minister is in trouble and the government is in damage control, government members use the device of taking spurious points of order or they speak to points of order and make spurious debating points. That is out of order. If Senator Kemp cannot answer a question in question time, and he cannot answer this one, he should sit down and take it on notice.
—There is no point of order and that was not an appropriate contribution either.

—The point I am making is that, in many cases, the real value of the voucher will improve. For example, this Christmas Senator Lundy wants to impose a 22 per cent wholesale sales tax on sporting goods. We are taking that off and imposing a 10 per cent GST. The short answer to Senator Cook is that the real value of vouchers may well rise.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: School Canteens

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. The A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999 provides, in section 40E, for a school tuckshop or canteen run by a non-profit body to elect to have all its supplies of food treated as input taxed. The cost of the GST on inputs will be passed to the students. This will be particularly hard on parents who organise school tuckshops and canteens run on a non-profit basis. Given that the government is now expecting to reap additional revenue through the higher business registration, will the minister consider making a determination under section 38(3) to extend GST-free status to all food supplied to students in school tuckshops run by non-profit parent-teacher organisations?

—I thank Senator Harris for that question. Tuckshops which are run by a non-profit body at a primary school or a secondary school and which supply only food may choose to be input taxed—that is their choice—and they will be outside the GST system. Where this occurs, the tuckshop will not charge GST on sales of food, but it will not be entitled to claim input tax credits for GST paid on its purchases. In this case, the tuckshop's revenue can be excluded from the annual turnover of the non-profit body for GST registration purposes. People will make their own judgments, but I think many parent associations will choose to be input taxed and not charge GST on food. That is a choice that they will have. That is another area where this government is flexible. We are providing options to people.

answer.para: The other point I think Senator Harris referred to was a windfall rise in GST revenue. Senator Harris, I think you were probably referring to an article which appeared in the Financial Review yesterday. The increase in estimates of GST registrations reflects both the normal increase in new business registrations from year to year, more up-to-date ATO data and, of course—thanks to this government—a stronger economy. They are the economic parameters. Growth factors are already factored into the Treasury revenue estimates for the GST. The growth in business numbers therefore, I am advised, would not of itself result in any increase in revenue over and above the current Treasury estimates.

The point I want to make to the Senate—and we have had a number of questions today on this issue—is that this government is providing flexibility for non-profit bodies. In the case of school tuckshops, there is a flexibility. You have to view this whole package. Many families will be $40 to $50 a week better off as a result of our tax package. The fact of the matter is, as we discussed with Senator Cook with respect to the voucher issue, that many families are going to be better off. They will have more money in their pockets. This is something that this government is very proud of. I hope that provides the response that you were seeking. We will not be going further, but I think that is a response which shows the flexibility that this government has in relation to making sure that we have a system which is fair to all types of organisations.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My supplementary question goes back to the original question to some extent. The question was whether the government would give, through section 38(3), a GST-free status to the food. That was the basis of the question. That would allow them to not have to pay the GST or decide whether they would claim inputs or not. Bearing that in mind, if the government did exercise that consideration, would the minister be able to inform the chamber what the relative costs of granting that concession would be?
—I do not have any figures here at the moment which could assist you, but I will look to see whether there are any figures that I am able to supply to you, Senator.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable Organisations

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of the Treasurer's statement yesterday where he said:

question.para: So that if a charity wants to stay outside the system, and it's up to it how it structures its activities, unless the project is going over $100 000 they can stay right outside the system.
How does this statement accord with the Treasurer's press release of 29 October where he said:
This means that, where the unit's turnover is less than $50 000, the unit can choose whether it registers for GST or not.
The Treasurer further stated:
Where the unit has a turnover of $50 000 or more, it will have to register separately for GST.
Can the Assistant Treasurer just try to inform us what the registration threshold is—$50,000 or $100,000? If the Treasurer himself is not sure, how will charities know?

talk.start.para: —That was the whole point of the announcement yesterday. I am very glad that Senator Sherry referred to the Treasurer's comments because I think they are extremely important, and it provides me with an opportunity to properly inform the Senate exactly what the Treasurer said. He said:

answer.para: Well, they can structure their affairs so that they can take advantage of it on individual fundraising activities.
This was an issue that Senator Crowley raised with us.

talk.start.para: —Hang on, she's gone.
—Yes, Senator Crowley seems to have departed. The Treasurer said:

answer.para: So that if a charity wants to stay outside the system, and it's up to it how it structures its activities, unless the project is going over $100 000 they can stay right outside the system.
Then he went on to say:
Well, staying outside the system means that they don't have any registration—they don't have any advantages of the GST—but of course they don't have any price requirements in relation to the GST.

The Treasurer then went on to make the very important point—a useful point to sum up this question time—that there are some 156 countries that have a GST type system. These countries are not going back to the Labor Party wholesale sales tax. No-one is arguing that they should go back to the Labor Party wholesale sales tax system, except maybe the Labor Party. As I have said in this chamber before, the truth of the matter is that the hardest question you ever get in this chamber is: what does the Labor Party stand for?

talk.start.para: —There's no answer, really.
—As my colleague Senator Alston said, there is no answer to that question. We do not know what your tax policy is. You do not know what your tax policy is.
—No GST.
—No GST? I hope I have clarified the position for Senator Sherry.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The point of the question went to why the Treasurer on one day said the threshold was $50,000 and on another day said it was $100,000. If the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are not sure about how the new tax will operate—and the Assistant Treasurer has never had any idea about how it will operate—what hope do voluntary organisations, small businesses and ordinary Australians have? What happened to the simple new tax?
—The answer to that is this—and it is not me; it is the Salvation Army. This is what the Salvation Army said yesterday.
—The Salvation Army will speak for charities, not you. It is this:

answer.para: The Salvation Army is now comfortable with the GST with the compensation that has been provided by the government. We have signed off on it more or less.

talk.start.para: —Wasn't that just the bloke who answered the phone and was trying to be helpful?
—Senator Evans, you should not be talking across the chamber in that fashion. There is an appropriate time for you to intervene and debate the issue, and that is after question time.
—I must say to the senator who made the interjection that it was a most disgraceful interjection. I hope the Salvation Army—
—Read the whole thing.

—I am happy to read the whole thing. If any of my colleagues want to stand up after question time and take note, I hope that they will be able to read the whole thing into the record to see what an utterly bogus, hopeless group the Labor Party has become under the leadership of Beazley in the other place and Senator Faulkner in this chamber.
—Madam Deputy President, I take a point of order. I invite the minister to table the document, if he is so confident of its contents.
—There is no point of order. Senator Kemp?
—No.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Charitable Organisations

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to questions without notice asked by senators today, relating to the goods and services tax.

During question time once again the inadequacy of this government in explaining the GST was revealed. There is no explanation at all as to why a rapacious government like this would want to impose a tax on Australian charities. The charitable movement in Australia is an honourable one. The charitable movement in Australia is driven by the idealism of many people who make personal sacrifices to see that Australians in greater need than them receive services. And what is the government's way of honouring that effort by many volunteer Australian charitable workers? Its way of honouring it is to tax them—and not only to tax them. Now that opposition to that tax has been raised by the charitable organisations themselves—
Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise in this chamber. I ask speakers to address the chair and for interjections to cease.

—In the debate we have just had during question time, Senator Kemp said, `What does the Labor Party stand for?' Well, it stands for a lot of things, none of which he said it stood for, of course. One of the things it does stand for, clearly and up-front and in your face, is no GST. Under that heading that also means no GST—
—Your leader said you will only roll it back.
—Oh, why don't you drop dead!
—Order! Senator Campbell, would you please withdraw that imputation.
—The Labor Party's position is they support rolling back a GST. They support the GST but we are not sure by how much. So it is a lie to say they don't support the GST—an unmitigated lie.
—Order, Senator Campbell!
—I withdraw.
—We stand for no GST and we voted in this chamber against a GST—
—That's rubbish! You hypocrite!
—You know it, and you are only envious—
—Order! Senator Campbell, you have made an unparliamentary comment. Would you please withdraw it.
—I withdraw.
—We stand for no GST on charities and we stand for no cash-for-comment blackmail on Australian charities.
—Tell the truth. Aren't you capable of telling the truth?
—Order!

—You have never made it to the ministry and you are very keen to get there. Fortunately, the Prime Minister in overlooking you, Senator Campbell, for front bench preference has made the right decision. It is a decision I applaud him for. Today I received an email, which all senators received, from the honorary secretary of the Motor Neurone Disease Research Institute, who says in part:

speech.para: I have had conflicting opinions about whether the GST will apply to our operation. If it does there will be 10 per cent less money available for research. The institute exists to provide funds for research into a devastating terminal disease of considerable cruelty, of unknown cause and no cure.
She goes on:

The doubt about application of GST seems to me to hinge on one factor: Will the production of a report on completed research be considered to be an outcome and will the allocation of funds be considered pay for that outcome? If the institute's support for research is liable for GST then we have a situation in which there will be 10 per cent reduction in funded research, research which is vital to those living with motor neurone disease. Their fate is a cruel enough one without having the hard raised funding reduced by taxation.

That is from a leading charitable organisation doing valuable work on a disease that some Australians are afflicted with. The government should show sympathy. There is no sympathy here, other than, `We will teach you how to evade the tax.' Let me come back to that in a minute. Today I have a press report from the Daily Liberal , a newspaper in country New South Wales, dated Tuesday of this week, which states:
"Complying with GST would cost the Western region diocese of St Vincent de Paul at least $40,000 a year," it was claimed yesterday.
It goes on to say:
That is what St Vincent de Paul say will be the effect of it.

This is a tax imposed by the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Democrats. We know that there have been talks going on behind the scenes because their backbench has been stampeded by this insensitive, unfeeling, impersonal tax being imposed on Australian charities. But what sympathy do we get from these parties about the plight of Australian charities and the need to turn every dollar they raise to the benefit of the charitable purposes for which they exist? Senator Murray, the Democrat spokesman on taxation, said today, `The fact is that we agreed charities would be within the new tax system. For those charities who don't want to be in the new tax system, well, they are going to be.' That is an unfeeling, unsympathetic attitude to Australian charities trying to raise a quid by the local raffle, by the lamington drive, by the cake stall, to serve the needs of their charitable organisations. The response from the government is to say, `Restructure your affairs', but restructuring your affairs means a new legal entity, a new set of books, a new auditor, and you people use it on administration, not on services. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook, you can keep on trying but you are not going to get there.
—Address the chair, please, Senator Eggleston.

—Through the chair, of course, Madam Deputy President. As long as Senator Cook keeps trying, he is not going to make the case that charities do not accept the GST. As was said on ABC national television on the 7.30 Report last night, Mr Daley from the Salvation Army said:

speech.para: It's a fact of payments out and then receiving payments back. We're satisfied that all the issues have been dealt with and that we're not going to be jeopardised in any way, or it's not going to be a negative for us.

That sums it up pretty well, doesn't it? Here you have a spokesman for the Salvation Army saying that they are not at all unhappy about the way charities will be treated under the new tax system. So, regardless of Senator Cook's attempts, the fact remains that across the board charities are quite happy with the way this system will work.

Let us think about how it will affect the clients of charities. What does the new tax system mean for the clients of charities and will they benefit? In fact, the clients of charities will be much better off under the new tax system. They will be better off because there will be a real increase in pensions and allowances which will give them more spending power. They will be better off because there will be tax cuts worth $12 billion a year which will benefit low income earners and give them more spending power. The beneficiaries of charities will be better off because there will be an increase in family benefits. There will be a reduction in the incidence of poverty traps, and the new tax system will underpin our social security safety net, provide better education services and better health services. So, in a multitude of ways, the beneficiaries of charities will benefit from the new tax system.

talk.start.para: —You don't believe this.
—I believe every word of it, Senator Faulkner, and I know that you know in your heart that it is true that these people will benefit.
—You are more stupid than I thought you were.
—Senator Faulkner, there is a hollow ring—
—Order! Senator Eggleston, address the chair, please, and try to ignore those interjections.

—because there is no doubt that the ALP will keep the GST when and if they ever return to power. Paul Keating wanted to introduce a tax like this. Here we are: it is on the agenda, it has happened. When you come back into office you will leave it there because you know that most countries in the OECD have this kind of indirect tax system. This was a very necessary step forward that Australia had to take. As a matter of public policy the ALP will not remove it.

speech.para: Let us look at how the GST will affect charities. First of all, non-commercial activities which will not be subject to the GST include supplies that are less than 50 per cent of the market value of such items, supplies that are less than 50 per cent of the cost to the charities providing the supply, or the supply of second-hand donated goods. It is true that the commercial activities of charities will be treated the same as the commercial activities of any ordinary business to ensure that ordinary businesses are not put at a competitive disadvantage. Charities will be entitled to register for the GST if they so desire and if their gross income is above the threshold levels, which will mean they will generally be able to claim back the GST paid on all their inputs as input credits. Fundraising done through sponsorship from businesses will be largely unaffected by the GST.

talk.start.para: —You believe all this, do you?
—I do believe it, and I know you do, too, Senator Faulkner. Here you are pretending that you do not see the benefits of this tax.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, cease interjecting. Senator Eggleston, please address the chair and ignore those interjections.

—I will, Madam Deputy President. I know that you as Deputy President would not want to see any persons like Senator Faulkner on the opposite side making misleading statements about not believing in the benefits of this tax system. Fundraising for charities done through donations—(Time expired)

—People at home who have been listening to the events of the parliament in the last few days should be left in no doubt at all that Ebenezer Scrooge is not in fact a fictional character in a story book but that Ebenezer Scrooge is alive and well in the hearts of each and every member of the federal government. What we have seen this week from this debacle of the impact of the GST on charities is that this government is very strong on taxing the weak and very weak on taxing the strong or the rich members of our society.

speech.para: We have a government that wants to turn charities into tax collectors. We have a government that is also quite inconsistent about its policies and where it is going. Yesterday Senator Kemp stood up in the Senate and told us that World Vision sponsorship, for example, could be subject to the tax. The GST will be payable on money you pay to World Vision to sponsor a little child overseas. At the same time, in the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister was forced to declare a backdown, whereby a GST exemption for child sponsorships would apply. We have heard a great deal of inconsistency about their policy on the GST. If the ordinary person sitting at home does not understand this policy, you could well understand why. Even the members of this government do not know how this policy is going to apply.

We now have a GST on compassion. We have a GST on the goodwill in people's hearts. Let us look at the elderly volunteers, for example, who run a stall at the base hospital in Orange. They raise over $200,000 per year, probably using old ice-cream containers or tins such as that for a till, and donate over $100,000 to that hospital because they believe in the cause. They believe that they are trying to raise some money for the hospital. They will now be caught up in the GST bungle.

The answer today from this government is that charities will now have a choice. They will not have a choice. The choice will be that if you have a turnover of under $100,000, you can opt to be part of the system or not. If your turnover is over $100,000, you are in the system. The choice is either whether they bother with all the paperwork and try to recoup some of the money back that they will be paying on the GST or whether they will say it is all too hard.

The real essence of this is that there will be a decline in the number of volunteers in this country who willingly give their time to charities and volunteer to bank this money or do the limited paperwork that is now required. Charitable organisations will be relying more and more on fewer and fewer people. No-one will be bothered being a tax collector for this government when they want to spend their time raising money and assisting the charities that they believe are worthwhile assisting. At the end of the day, we will see less money for activities and those people that those charities are designed to assist.

Nobody in the community believes Senator Eggleston or Senator Kemp when they say that this will be a good thing for people who are poor and struggling and for organisations that need these extra funds. Nobody believes that. I cannot believe that the government is so out of touch with the anger in the community at this time as this GST debacle rolls out before their eyes.

We have a tax on compassion. We are turning charities into tax collectors. We really want the government to stand up and say categorically that they will be exempting charities and their fundraising efforts from the GST. That is what ACOSS have called for and that is what charities have called for from day one. They want a complete exemption from this debacle and a complete acknowledgment by this government that they play a very valuable role in this community. That role will now be turned into nothing less than a tax collector for the federal government.

talk.start.para: —We have listened to various senators speak in here today. One thing we really know is that, as far as the Labor Party is concerned, it is a great pretence that they do not believe in the GST. If the Labor Party does not believe in the GST, why do they not come out and say that they will get rid of it in the unlikely event they are elected? Not once have they been prepared to say that they will get rid of the GST. With that in mind, one can only assume that they actually support a GST. They will not at any stage get up and say that they will remove the GST in the unlikely event that they are elected.

speech.para: Senator Crossin will not say it. She makes statements that are simply not true. There is absolutely nothing to substantiate her claim that the number of volunteers will decline. Volunteers have been declining under the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax. They have been declining in number over the years. All these service clubs that have been mentioned today have been declining in number all the time we have had the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax. So do not blame a decline in numbers on the GST.

In question time, Senator Cook spoke about the value of a $40 voucher this Christmas compared with a $40 voucher next Christmas. Under the sound economic management of this government, that $40 voucher could actually be a voucher worth well over $100 if that person is paying a mortgage on their house. In the time that this government has been in power, we have been able to put more than approximately $100 week per week extra in a house buyer's pocket because interest rates are so much lower than they were when we came to office. They have more spending power now.

Senator Cook did not say anything about the giver of that $40 having income tax cuts next July. He conveniently forgot that. The $12 billion worth of income tax cuts being delivered by this government will allow somebody who gives a $40 gift voucher this year to actually give more next year.
Senator O'Brien interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator O'Brien can say all he likes by way of interjection, but the proof is in the pudding. Senator O'Brien is another of those members opposite who does not want the GST removed. He wants to keep it there in the unlikely event that those opposite happen to form a government.

speech.para: Senator Cook's question about a $40 voucher was naturally aimed at getting some cheap headline. He never mentioned anything about the real increase in pensions and allowances that will occur. He never mentioned anything about the $12 billion worth of tax cuts that will flow on to Australian taxpayers on 1 July next year. He never mentioned the increase in family benefits. There was not a word about the positive side of tax reform. There was only the harping negative side as he tried to find specific instances and nitpick. Even then, he did not come up with the correct facts.

Senator Cook never said anything about reducing the incidence of poverty traps. One of the key planks of this taxation reform is to try to reduce the incidence of poverty traps, something which you did not even attempt to tackle during 13 years of Labor government. I remember Senator Murray saying at one of our tax inquiries that this is the first time any government in recent times has done anything to try to tackle the poverty traps that exist and the disincentives for people to work or to work harder or to earn more. There was not a word from Senator Cook about the new tax system, which is going to underpin our social security safety net, education, health and all of those other things that are so important to all the members of our community.

My advice to the Labor Party is to stop the scaremongering tactics. Do not frighten Australians. Everything that you have said today is not designed to present the truth to the public, it is designed to try to scare the public into believing something that simply will not happen. We had Senator Crossin saying that the number of volunteers will decline, as though the number has been increasing in the last number of years. We all know that all voluntary organisations over a long period of time have struggled to maintain their numbers. The Labor Party actually like the GST because they have no intention of removing it. I know Senator McKiernan is another one who thinks that we should keep it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —With regard to the remarks of the previous speaker, Senator Ferguson, I am not one of the people in this chamber who can be accused of getting up here and scaremongering in the past, and I am not going to do it at the moment. What I am going to do, though, is something quite unusual. I am going to quote from the Daily Liberal . This is a newspaper that operates in the western district of New South Wales. It is not within my constituency but, because of its name and because of what the editorial of yesterday says, it is well worth while reading it into the record to see where this scaremongering is coming from and to see where the facts and the truths, and where the fears of the charitable organisations, are coming from. It will not take very long to read. The editorial says:

speech.para: The western region branch of St Vincent de Paul Society believes it will cost $40,000 to comply with GST regulations when they come into force on July 1, 2000.

This particular case, which won't be uncommon among charities and other community non-profit groups, highlights the difference between the current system of exemptions and a system immersed in paperwork.
At the moment—
Senator Ferguson should listen to this—

registered charities and some other groups are exempt from paying wholesale sales tax. It's a fairly simple procedure requiring a registration number and little or no paperwork during the transaction.
Under the Federal Government's GST guidelines there is a significantly more complex system which will tax corporate sponsorships, fetes, food vouchers, refuges and even sheltered workshops.

The Australian Tax Office has admitted GST compliance costs will eat into charity funds and volunteers will need training to cope with GST paperwork and personally bear the additional out-of-pocket expenses.

It is a significant quote coming from the Daily Liberal . I believe it is quite an accurate portrayal of the fears that abound in our community of those organisations which provide such a service to the Australian community.

Even Mr Costello has heard of these fears. Yesterday in the House of Representatives Mr Costello tried to calm nerves, but what he also did was to actually tell it like it is. He has told the charities that operate in Australia that, whichever way they turn, they are going to get it in the neck. They are going to get it in the neck because if they register that they have over $100,000 in inputs, they will have all the associated paperwork. If they do not have $100,000 in inputs and seek not to register, then they are going to be hit with the GST on the inputs. So whichever way they turn they are going to cop it—they are going to cop it going and they are going to cop it coming back as well. Today's Adelaide Advertiser says:
And Mr Costello said large charities with big turnovers would still escape the tax by separating their individual activities into units worth less than $100,000.
But by doing this, charities would still be caught in the GST net because they would not be allowed to claim the rebates for the GST on products they purchase.

For example, a parent group with a turnover of less than $100,000 would still have to pay the GST on items such as some foods for the tuckshop, raffle prizes and clothes for the uniform shop. The group could sell the items GST-free but would not be able to claim back any of the GST it paid for the stock.

As we approach the last year of the current century, Ebenezer Scrooge is well and truly alive. But what is the identity of Ebenezer Scrooge? Is it John Howard? Is it Mr Costello? Or is it Senator Lees?

talk.start.para: —Please do not reflect upon a member of the other house or a senator.
—The answer to that question is still to be found out.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Air Fares

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government (Senator Ian Macdonald) to a question without notice asked by Senator Greig today, relating to airline competition and regional air services.

In his answer, Senator Ian Macdonald repeated his commitment to competition and to rural and regional Australia, and also indicated his enthusiasm for and interest in the proposal by Virgin to work within Australia. It is true that there is considerable interest and concern over the proposal by Virgin Airlines to operate here. I think this concern and interest is in two parts.

Firstly, there is the excitement from many people in the general community about the prospect of a third airline operating within Australia and what this new competition might mean in terms of cheaper air fares. I can remember the immense support in my home state of Western Australia for the emergence some years ago of Compass Airlines and the way in which it dramatically altered the cost of interstate flights, which plunged dramatically and for the first time made it possible for many West Australians who previously had not been able to afford interstate airfares to then do so. This jolt to the airline duopoly has had long-reaching effects and the legacy of Compass to today's consumers is a domestic airfares regime that is more accessible and affordable than it was in the past.

Alongside the understandable interest in the emergence of Virgin Airlines is the very real concern about the cherry picking operations that Virgin proposes to employ. That is, by choosing to work only the main capital city trunk routes—largely Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane—the pressure will almost certainly be applied to both Ansett and Qantas to lower their trunk route fares in response to the competition from Virgin. This will undoubtedly apply equal pressure to both Ansett and Qantas to either increase fares on their less popular and less frequented sectors or perhaps to wind back these services altogether.

Today's press and the Brisbane Courier-Mail report that Mr Richard Branson's Virgin Airlines has crossed its first major hurdle towards establishing a third domestic airline after the federal government granted foreign investment approval. Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, yesterday announced the approval under new rules which allow foreign carriers to establish new domestic aviation businesses provided they are in the national interest. This raises the question of what constitutes the national interest, and it is in this context that I raise my real concerns about the potential downgrading of services to rural and regional areas, or perhaps the more likely scenario of low frequency sectors used by Ansett and Qantas being the subject of price hikes as these airlines continue to service those areas not serviced by Virgin but under the added financial pressure being placed on them by competition.

Competition in and of itself is not a bad thing, but it can only work fairly if there is a level playing field. In a previous answer on this matter when it was raised by my colleague Senator Woodley, Senator Macdonald said:
This particular issue is one thing I think the government just has to keep an eye on to make sure there is not any diminution in the bush.

But this issue is about not only how the emergence of Virgin may adversely affect the bush, but also the way in which less popular sectors such as Perth to Adelaide or Adelaide to Darwin may be affected by potential price increases. The Australian Competition and Consumer Council, the ACCC, would appear to be well placed to monitor and report on this, particularly in terms of potential price increases as a result of what might rightly be seen as unfair trade practices. Again Senator Macdonald made reference to this in a previous answer to my colleague Senator Woodley when asked about the demise of Compass Airlines and the apparent difficulties imposed on it by Qantas or Ansett in terms of airport space and general terminal facilities.

Today I asked the minister whether the Commonwealth intends to use the prices power of the ACCC and whether it intends to supplement such powers as necessary to ensure that users of regional services do not suffer an increase in relative fare levels arising from the entry of Virgin Australia into the domestic intercapital routes. In reply, the minister indicated that, if any adverse illegal or improper behaviour towards Virgin could be shown, then it ought to be directed to the ACCC. It is a reply that very strongly suggests reaction rather than action.

I think, however, that I express the views and concerns of many Australians when I say that, to date, the government has not been altogether convincing with its assurances of consumer protection and consumer equity for those travellers in the less popular flight sectors currently serviced, and well serviced for the most part, by the existing duopoly. In a sense what many Australians are asking is: will the Commonwealth establish safeguards to ensure that the quality and frequency of regional airline services operated by Qantas and Ansett are not compromised by the entry of Virgin Australia? While the government has made reassuring noises about the benefits of competition and its professed commitment to rural and regional areas—and by implication to more isolated cities such as Perth—there has not yet been any real tangible action to match these words with particular regard to ensuring equity for domestic airline travellers. The government needs to make clear its attitude towards the prospect of Virgin Australia as a fully foreign owned company. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
