subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I withdraw my second reading amendment.

—I will make a few observations on the debate on Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1999 . Senator Bartlett, your voice was a little bit quiet but I assume that you have withdrawn your second reading amendment.
—Yes.

—Thank you. There have been a number of contributions from senators. The new superannuation investment rules were announced in the 1998-99 budget. The investment rules are designed to reduce risk to superannuation savings and to ensure that superannuation is preserved for retirement. The bill will ensure that the fundamental principle that superannuation funds cannot borrow is maintained. This serves to limit the risk to superannuation savings from geared investments and will also ensure that superannuation savings are used for retirement purposes. In doing so, the bill will benefit the community as a whole by ensuring that billions of dollars of superannuation tax concessions provided each year are used for their intended purpose, thereby reducing the burden on future age pension outlays.

speech.para: An important aspect of the bill will be to enhance the ability of small business owners to use their superannuation savings to invest in their own premises by allowing a small superannuation fund to invest up to 100 per cent of its assets in business premises that are leased to members or to the employer sponsor of the fund. The bill contains a number of transitional arrangements to assist superannuation funds in adapting to the new arrangements. The government has consulted with key industry and professional groups on the bill. The bill was referred to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and Financial Services, which reported on 25 November 1999. After careful examination of the report, the government has decided to respond to some of the issues which have been raised.

Firstly, on non-geared trusts: a number of groups such as ASPA have argued that, while the broad thrust of SLAB4 is appropriate, there should be some scope for investments in non-geared related trusts. For instance, it has been argued that this is a means of jointly owning property with a related party as an alternative to a tenants-in-common relationship. To meet this requirement, the government will move an amendment to create a power to make a regulation to exempt particular classes of assets from being in-house assets. The exception will apply only to a superannuation fund with fewer than five members that invests in a company or trust which meets specified requirements.

These requirements include that the company or trust does not borrow; it does not invest in or loan money to individuals or other entities other than deposits with financial institutions; it does not acquire assets from a related party of the superannuation fund other than business real property; it does not lease assets to related parties or enter into lease arrangements other than a legally binding lease of business or real property to a related property on an arms length basis; and it conducts all other transactions on an arms length basis. The government will consult with accounting and other industry bodies in developing a definition of non-geared company or trust that meets these requirements.

As to the start date, concerns were expressed about the lapse of time since the original announcement on 12 May 1998. In response the government will move an amendment to ensure that the change to the in-house provisions will apply only from the date of introduction of the legislation—11 August 1998. The change to allow a small superannuation fund to use 100 per cent of its assets to acquire business real property from a related party will continue to apply from 12 May 1999.

Let me say in conclusion that, by limiting the risk to superannuation savings and ensuring that superannuation is used for the intended purpose of retirement income, the bill will set a sound framework for superannuation savings for decades to come. As I have already mentioned, some government amendments will be moved at the committee stage. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 1 to 4:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 13, page 6 (lines 14 and 15), omit "any of paragraphs 71(1)(b) to (f) or paragraph 71(1)(h)", substitute "paragraph 71(1)(b), (ba), (c), (d), (e), (f), (h) or (j)".
(2) Schedule 1, item 28, page 12 (after line 31), at the end of the item, add:
; or (j) an asset included in a class of assets specified in the regulations:
(i) not to be in-house assets of any fund; or
(ii) not to be in-house assets of a class of funds to which the fund belongs.
For this purpose, a class of assets may consist of, but is not limited to, assets that are investments in entities that undertake, or do not undertake, specified activities.
(3) Schedule 1, item 34, page 14 (line 24), omit "(i)", substitute "(j)".
(4) Schedule 1, page 14 (after line 27), after item 34, insert:

Omit all the words from and including "may" to and including "was", substitute "or regulations under paragraph (1)(j) may be expressed to have taken effect at a time earlier than the time when the determination or regulations were".
Note: The heading to subsection 71(5) is altered by inserting "or paragraph (1)(j) regulations " after "determinations ".

These amendments will allow a regulation making power to be used to make an exception. This will apply only to a superannuation fund with fewer than five members that invests in a company or trust which meets the specified requirements.

talk.start.para: —I wish to make a few comments in respect of amendments Nos 2 to 4. Government amendment No. 2 will allow the government to make regulations to exempt certain assets or classes of assets from being treated as in-house assets. This is an enormously wide power and, without having seen the regulations, how can the Senate be sure of what the government is doing? There is absolutely no need for the government to do this, and Labor is opposing this amendment. Government amendment No. 3 is a consequential amendment. Government amendment No. 4 relates to section 71 of the superannuation industry supervision legislation, known as SIS, which determines the meaning of in-house assets. Currently section 71E allows for the commissioner to make a determination—not a regulation but a determination, which is an important point—as to whether an asset should be taken to be an in-house asset. That determination is a disallowable instrument under section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

speech.para: Section 71(5) allows for the determination to be retrospective. That is, the commissioner's determination given in writing to the trustee of a super fund may be expressed to have taken effect at a time earlier than the time when the determination was made. That is seen as being positive, as it means that if a superannuation fund asks for clarification of the status of a particular asset, it can be given in-house asset status from the date the super fund acquired it rather than from the date the commissioner makes the determination. However, the government's amendment No. 4 is asking that regulations be included. That is, the government is asking the Senate to allow it to make regulations that can operate retrospectively. We ran into this type of request from the government in a previous debate on the recently passed so-called surcharge tax amendment bills, and the Senate made a clear decision, supported by the Australian Democrats, that the government should not have a power to make retrospective regulations.

Firstly, it must override the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to do so, and I ask the government whether or not its amendment is correct. Senator Kemp will recall that the opposition has previously corrected his amendments. Section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act specifically relates to the timing of the regulations and states that a regulation has no effect if it takes effect before the date of notification if the rights of a person would be so affected as to disadvantage that person. Secondly, liabilities would be imposed on a person in respect of anything done or omitted to be done before the date of notification. That is, regulations shall generally not be retrospective, particularly if they disadvantage a person or impose a liability. It could be argued, if regulations were made about the status or otherwise of in-house assets, that they would always be positive and that section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act would not come into play because no-one would be worse off.

However, how does the Senate determine whether regulations which it has not seen yet are positive or negative? How can we make this decision? In the case of the so-called surcharge tax bills which were recently passed, the Senate acted decisively to take the offending provision out of the bill. These provisions were to allow the government the capacity to override section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act. Retrospective regulations should not generally be allowed to be made. Certainly the Labor opposition and the Australian Democrats have acted on this before, and I call on the Australian Democrats to act in the same way as we did on the previous occasion and not to support government amendment No. 4.

talk.start.para: —I want to indicate that the Democrats will support this and other amendments. As I said in the second reading debate, we think they go to many of the problems that were identified by those who made submissions to the inquiry. We support the thrust of them, and we were instrumental in assisting to develop them as well. There is a question I want to put to the minister, and it relates to the fact that this amendment allows the regulations to specify assets. I want to ask how the minister will proceed to develop definitions of real property and with whom he will consult. If we could get some assurances on the record about that process, Minister, I think we would be rather more confident that this will happen to our satisfaction.

—In relation to the matters raised by Senator Sherry, any regulations would be beneficial in the sense of excluding things from being in-house assets. Regulations come before this chamber. If Senator Sherry and the Senate are unhappy with the regulations, they have the power to disallow the regulations. That provides the safety check that Senator Sherry was referring to.

speech.para: In relation to the matters that Senator Allison raised, let me assure you that the government will consult with accounting and other industry bodies in developing a definition of non-geared company or trust that meets these requirements. This is a consultative government, and we will ensure that there is a proper process of consultation, which I know you would want.

talk.start.para: —I have a couple of other points to raise. Apparently the Democrats have entered into an agreement with the government in respect of the regulations that we are considering. I point out to the Senate that the changes to the amendments that are being presented to the chamber, as a result of the deal between the government and the Australia Democrats, do not satisfy Labor's central concerns and principles with this legislation. They do not deal with the issues or the concerns that were raised by the witnesses that came before the Senate committee. We received some of the strongest submissions and evidence that I have ever seen before any committee in my time in the Senate opposing the central principles of this legislation

speech.para: I will make it clear for the record: the amendments that the Democrats, together with the government, have drafted do not deal with those problems. They do not deal with the five key criteria that I outlined in my speech during the second reading debate. They do not deal with the first point: that the government has provided no substantive evidence of a systemic abuse by DIY super funds of the current investment rules. They do not deal with the point that, if there are concerns in this area, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), which was passed with the support of the opposition, will largely address the problems, if there are problems. There are other ways of tightening existing laws that will better address the perceived problems. For example, the tax office will now be regulating in this area. They do not deal with the difficulties that this legislation will cause for some small businesses. They do not deal with the difficulties of some people in rural and regional Australia. Whilst some of these amendments may have improved the situation slightly, they do not go to the heart of the problems that Labor has with this bill.

I would like Senator Allison to explain why, on this occasion, she is supporting retrospective regulations when we have not seen the regulations. She is taking the government on trust. On a previous occasion when we considered this approach, we were not prepared to do it in respect of superannuation. I do not want to extend the debate, but this government has a pretty patchy record on superannuation. I am being mild in my criticism because I am aware of the time constraints we are under. I would not be taking anything on trust in respect of this government and superannuation. We do not believe there should be an overriding of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. There would need to be extraordinary circumstances for that to occur. On the argument advanced by the government to date, we are not faced with any sort of reasonably extraordinary circumstance to warrant the Acts Interpretation Act being overridden in a way that is occurring here. I would like a response from Senator Allison. These amendments do not satisfy our concerns about the legislation and we will still be opposing the legislation.

talk.start.para: —I think it has already been pointed out to Senator Sherry by the minister that the regulations are a disallowable instrument of the Senate. If we are not satisfied with them, that is the action that we can take. I can assure you, Senator Sherry, that we will not be afraid to disallow if that is found to be necessary by the Senate. We will be looking forward to seeing what those definitions are and taking advice, as no doubt you will, about whether or not they pass the scrutiny of the Senate.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move government amendments (5) to (11):

speech.para: (5) Schedule 1, heading to section 71A, page 15 (line 15), omit "pre-12 May 1998 ", substitute "pre-11 August 1999 ".
(6) Schedule 1, heading to section 71B, page 16 (line 28), omit "pre-12 May 1998 ", substitute "pre-11 August 1999 ".
(7) Schedule 1, item 35, page 22 (lines 1 and 2), omit all the words from and including "7.30" to and including "1998", substitute "the end of 11 August 1999".

(8) Schedule 1, item 46, page 24 (lines 10 to 14), omit all the words from and including "after" to and including "(the test time )", substitute "after the end of 11 August 1999 (the test time ), unless the asset was acquired under a contract entered into before the test time".
(9) Schedule 1, item 46, page 24 (line 18), omit "the test time", substitute "7.30 pm by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory on 12 May 1998".
(10) Schedule 1, item 46, page 24 (line 29), omit "the introduction time", substitute "the test time".
(11) Schedule 1, item 46, page 25 (line 3), omit "the introduction time", substitute "the test time".

These amendments ensure the changes to the in-house provisions will apply only from the date of introduction of the legislation, that is, 11 August 1999. As the amendments have only recently been agreed to, they are not accompanied by a supplementary explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: —These amendments improve the bill. They do not deal with all the central concerns, but they do deal with one issue. They effectively shift the date from the budget announcement in May 1998 to 11 August 1999. The reason that that needs to occur—amongst many other matters that unfortunately are not occurring—is that it took so long for the government to present detailed legislation to the parliament. It took 18 months after the budget announcement, and this caused enormous uncertainty within those sections of the superannuation industry handling do-it-yourself superannuation. I know the minister on a number of occasions has said, `We consulted widely and we consulted for this time.' I point out to the Senate that we have some different provisions from the original budget announcement because there was such a backlash. But it took 18 months for the government to bring in the legislation. That is why we are considering this date. These amendments do improve it, but they do not deal with the other central concerns that Labor has.

speech.para: Whilst I am on my feet—and I am aware of the time—I might point out that I notice that the Australia Democrats have withdrawn the amendment that they were going to move in respect of same sex couples. That is regrettable.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is regrettable because the amendment would have required a report from the government. It was not actually amending the legislation. It is a sad day for the Democrats to be backing down on these types of issues, particularly when it was a pretty limp old amendment that the government apparently was not going to accept. It is inconsistent with the recommendations of the Senate select committee, of which Senator Watson was the chair. The government would not accept that amendment. Just so there is no argument, it says:

speech.para: "and that there be laid on the table, on or before the last sitting day in March 2000, details of all legislative changes that would be required to ensure the recognition and equal treatment of same-sex couples under all Commonwealth superannuation and taxation legislation".

For the life of me, I cannot see what the government objected to. It was not changing the law as such; it was about the handing down of a report. I think it is very disappointing that the Democrats will not be proceeding with what is not a particularly dramatic amendment anyway, but they can explain themselves to the various communities who are concerned about this issue. I have commented on this matter here because I know we want to deal with the bill prior to the conclusion of business this evening.

talk.start.para: —In answer to Senator Sherry's remarks about our second reading amendment, he will be pleased to know that a notice of motion on the amendment was put by my colleague Senator Bartlett this afternoon, and the Labor Party will have a chance to vote on that motion tomorrow. I look forward to the ALP's support.

speech.para: I point out that we will be supporting these government amendments too. We are pleased that the government recognised the hardship that would have arisen from the retrospectivi ty back to May 1998 that was embedded in the original bill. We think that bringing it forward to 11 August is a reasonable approach, together with allowing a much longer period for funds to comply—on to the year 2009.

talk.start.para: —I think the amendments reflect the wisdom of referring this bill to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and Financial Services. Most of the issues that were raised in that report have been picked up by the government. I thank the government for that. It will facilitate the operation of superannuation in Australia.

speech.para: I would like to remind Senator Sherry that the issue that he was referring to was largely addressed earlier in the superannuation No. 1 legislation that passed this parliament. That response was a very meaningful epoch-making response, and I do not think it is necessary to take the matter any further at the moment. I thank the minister for picking up these issues. It will certainly make distributions from funds a lot easier as a result of an ungeared unit trust. I thank the minister.

talk.start.para: —All I can say is that if you look at the evidence and the issues that were presented to the superannuation committee hearings on this matter, the amendments that the Democrats and the government have put together do not deal with many of the concerns raised by persons who appeared before the committee and the issues raised in the submissions. Frankly, I am not sure what Senator Watson was referring to in terms of SLAB 1. I assume it was same sex couples, was it, Senator Watson?
—Yes.

—Okay. I also point out to the Senate that we do have a private members bill in the House of Representatives, I think moved by my colleague Mr Albanese and seconded by Mr Danby. It is a very important piece of legislation. Again I say to the Democrats: if the government is fair dinkum on this, let us see that bill in here and being dealt with, as well as your proposed amendment.

speech.para: With due respect to you, Senator Allison, I think that, on this matter, the government is having the Democrats on. They do not intend to progress that issue at all. If they did, the bill would be in here for us to consider and to deal with this important issue with respect to superannuation and same sex couples. It is a fundamental right for a person who has superannuation moneys accumulated in their name to designate what they want done with their money. Governments have no place in interfering with that.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is a problem in a range of areas, Senator McGauran, not just with nomination of beneficiaries, but that is not the subject of the debate now. That will conclude my contribution. I make it clear that we are not happy. We do not believe the amendments satisfy the concerns that are being raised. We do not support this legislation. I will not be calling a division because of the time of year and the time of the evening, but I make it very clear that that is the Labor Party's position.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The United States magazine George is essentially representative of the mainstream of politics. It is American, previously edited by the late John F. Kennedy Jr, and has both Democrat and Republican columnists. So if you read an article in George about the impact of the Internet on politics, you know that IT has moved beyond the realm of specialised interest and into the mainstream.

speech.para: In fact, a casual browse of the Net demonstrates how seriously those involved in US politics take the power of the web. From George Bush Jr's presidential campaign to Hillary Clinton's run for the Senate to Donald Trump's campaign for the Reform Party nomination, American politicians are delving into this medium with unbridled enthusiasm. Even the Stop Hillary campaign gets a guernsey here and there. Each of these has a significant presence on the web—providing information, soliciting support and donations, and giving browsers the opportunity to ask questions or make comments. I can only imagine that, as the US presidential race heats up early next year, web presence will become increasingly important.

As important as IT is in US politics, so too is it in the Australian environment. The 1990s explosion of the Internet has already had enormous implications for political communication. The use of the World Wide Web, email, bulletin boards and other means of Internet based communication has increased enormously in what is really a relatively short period of time. After all, the Internet as we know it effectively only came into existence in recent decades. Whilst Her Majesty is said to have sent the first royal email in 1976, the advances of contemporary browsers, online shopping and audio are really developments of the 1990s.

As politicians, political parties, lobbyists, community organisations and individuals have all started to use these techniques, the impact that the new form of communication will have on politics, on communities and on the way we interact has also been considered. There are some very significant issues at the heart of this—issues like availability, access, skill renewal, and of course the impact on politics and politicians. Perhaps the most fundamental question for us is whether new technologies will somehow change the way that we interact with our constituencies. Some people believe that communication facilitated by IT between politicians and the community can introduce a more equitable relationship, allowing politicians and citizens to contribute equally.
Lawrence K. Grossman, former President of America's NBC News, says that new forms of communication based on IT will change contemporary politics. He said:
Gutenberg made everybody a reader, Xerox made everybody a publisher, and interactive telecommunications is making everybody a lobbyist.

That is a compelling proposition for anyone interested in engaging more people in the process of politics. But studies conducted in the United States indicate that whilst the new mediums of exchange on the Internet and email will have a great impact on political communication, they are in fact more likely to reinforce the existing structure of American politics than to change it. So whether the Net and email actually change the way people think about politics and politicians remains to be seen. Certainly there are differences between the American and Australian scenarios.

As most members and senators could attest—some more positively than others—the introduction of email facilities for members of this parliament has been greeted enthusiastically by our constituents. Certainly over recent times I, like all senators, have been on the receiving end of a number of email campaigns, from Jabiluka, to Internet censorship to, more recently, the situation in East Timor. The number of people using email to contact parliamentarians is increasing. What is undeniable is that devices like email and Internet sites are important tools for politicians and their constituents alike—and therein perhaps lies the difference with some of the historical comparisons I have made.

Perhaps the real test of this method of exchange will be how we as parliamentarians choose to respond to emails. The delivery of a message via electronic means does not change the validity of the message or make it more or less important than a letter or a fax, but it might actually change the expectations of the person who sends the message. The issue of how to respond to email messages is being considered right across international politics. People who email the US President get an email confirmation of their message and, if it is appropriate, a letter in response. The Prime Minister encourages members of the public to leave comments on his web site but to pursue detailed matters through other means, like contacting their local member or senator.

An ongoing challenge is dealing with the global nature of the Internet. As senators who represent a particular state, or members who represent an even more specific constituency in the lower house, the way in which the Net and email open up access to people from all over the world is a challenge that I suspect will be met in different ways by different members. Some might just hit `delete' whilst others might view email as they would a letter or a telephone inquiry from someone outside their constituency. The most important thing in all of this is that members and senators do not ignore the opportunity that the Internet and email create for us, and that constituent contact generated through new technologies is embraced enthusiastically.

In the Australian context, both federal and state parliamentarians have taken up the IT challenge with enthusiasm. Many members of this chamber have a Net presence, and many others are following suit. I think it is fair to say that members of the coalition are leading in many ways in the trend. To provide a central registry of all individual coalition members' home pages, I have published a directory that profiles the personal home pages of my coalition colleagues from the New South Wales and Commonwealth parlia ments. It is called Insite and a copy has been provided to the Parliamentary Library. It was launched recently at an event I organised in Sydney to celebrate both the growth of the IT industry and the important role of Australian women in this growth.

Two speakers addressed the launch of Insite. The first speaker was Barry O'Farrell, the New South Wales state member who is Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow minister for information technology. His portfolio passion is IT innovation in New South Wales and the potential boost for our state. He is a keen follower of a range of IT issues, including Internet content, Y2K challenges and IT training.

The second speaker that we enjoyed hearing from was Ruby Blessing. She has seen the average web browser go from a simple, text based interface with grey backgrounds and no animation to a fully integrated multimedia delivery tool. She is one of the world's leading web designers and has been a regular recipient of awards for her work. Acknowledged as the most prolific female web designer in the world, she has designed more than 100 corporate, institution and cultural web sites. Inducted into the Australian Business Women's Hall of Fame in 1999, she now operates a consultancy for businesses and cultural institutions wanting to take full advantage of the Internet and all forms of IT.
Ms Blessing shared a number of her experiences and thoughts in this area and, when remarking on the launch of Insite, said:

Browsing through . . . Insite I was impressed by the number of members embracing the Internet to inform and communicate with their electorates. Most were extremely up to date with a diverse range of content and features. Regardless of political persuasion, it's hard not to get excited about this sort of dynamic use of the Internet.

For politics in 1999 and beyond, the Internet and personal home pages offer a huge range of opportunities and advantages for parliamentarians, and Insite seeks to harness the growing involvement of members of the coalition in that area. I was pleased to see, for example, in putting it all together, that many Senate colleagues are keenly involved in leading the charge in engagement on the Net. Senators Boswell, Calvert, Gibson, Knowles, Troeth and Tambling and many of our lower house colleagues have extremely impressive sites. Since the publication of Insite even more have been raised with me or are under construction, and they will be in there as well. In commenting on the publication of Insite , the Prime Minister said that this initiative might act as a tool to `grow and encourage our colleagues to use online tools to keep in touch with our customers, the Australian public'. Hopefully, that is an opportunity everybody will take up.

At the same time as I launched Insite, I also took the opportunity to launch a new redeveloped web site of my own—easily found at www.marisepayne.com. It has already seen huge amounts of new traffic and I am very pleased with its progress. It is particularly interesting to hear from the people who are logging on—ranging from young people at school to professionals and retired workers from New South Wales, Australia and internationally. There is a huge diversity of interest, and that diversity is something I think we should encourage and facilitate.

Even my political party—the Liberal Party of New South Wales—is engaged in a major redevelopment and review of its web site. Under the guidance of Country Vice-President Robyn Parker it has been completely overhauled. Now if you log on you get information on the party, its parliamentary representations, regular publications and different parts of the organisation. The New South Wales Young Liberal Movement has gone through a similar process and has a very dynamic site that I think makes it comparable to any other youth political organisation in Australia.

Most importantly, though, in this whole process, the coalition and I, in particular, recognise the importance of utilising the new technologies to maximise our community interaction—to maximise our contact with our constituents in the most advanced and technologically progressive way. I can say with great assurance this evening that the coalition—in the parliament and in the states and territories—is taking up huge opportunities offered through the Internet, which is very commendable indeed. I think it is a fundamental part of our jobs as senators, and as members in the other place, to maintain an active interest and an active presence in this regard. I look forward to continuing to do that and to hearing from a lot more young people in particular through my web site.

subdebateinfo.title: Salmon Industry: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee Report

talk.start.para: —Tonight I would just like to say a few words about the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee interim report on the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the importation of salmon. The report is an interim report, and I am very pleased to see that the committee is taking this issue as seriously as it is. But, having said that, I would like to make a few comments with regard to evidence given to the committee, particularly by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

speech.para: I was somewhat amazed at evidence given by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on what is a very important issue for this country, being an agricultural producer in very significant terms, and it in turn being a very important part of our exports to other countries around the world. The quarantine matter that goes to salmon relates to the sanitary and phytosanitary agreement—or the SPS agreement—that has arisen out of the World Trade Organisation. We as a country played a very significant role in the development of the SPS agreement, so one would have thought that we would have had some degree of expertise in its application. But you certainly would not be able to glean that if you were to look at and take account of our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's performance before the committee. It would seem that they know very little of its workings.

I have spoken on the issue of salmon on a number of occasions with regard to the restrictions on the importation of not only Canadian salmon but also salmon from around the world. As we know, there are many diseases that occur in a range of species of fin fish. Arising out of the setting up of the World Trade Organisation, countries were required to bring into line the levels of pro tection—or the ALOP measures—that they would have in place.

As I said from the outset, we, AQIS and DFAT would lay claim to being major players in the development of the World Trade Organisation's sanitary and phytosanitary measures that relate to animal and human health. If that is the case, I have to say that I am just amazed that we have not been able to proceed appropriately. Back in 1994, we received applications from countries with regard to the restrictions that we had in place for the importation of salmon meats. AQIS, under WTO rules, was required to proceed to conduct an import risk analysis—and it did. In 1995 it brought down a draft report. The draft report contained recommendations to lift the existing restrictions which had been in place since 1975. Subsequently, it brought down a report in 1996 that recommended the maintenance of the restrictions.

There is a total inconsistency in that. What changed between 1995 and 1996? Little, I would suggest. What new scientific evidence came to light? None, I would suggest. That gave cause for concern at the WTO. The fact that when AQIS prepared their draft report in 1995 they gave copies of it to the Canadians in particular, who were joined by the US in their application to have our restrictions removed, is surprising, to say the least. It was a draft report. Little or no consultation had been conducted with recreational fishing people here, or even with those who are involved in farming of salmonoids in this country, not just in Tasmania. As I said, in 1996 they bought out a final report that recommended the retention of restrictions. Of course, it was quite obvious that the Canadians would actually take us to the WTO disputes panel. If we look at the WTO process in that respect, we can see that the panel of experts put together by the WTO when they were considering the processes that AQIS used in the conduct of its risk analysis raised questions about whether or not AQIS conducted their import risk analysis appropriately, and I think rightly so.

The very relevant point about that is this: we lay claim to being major contributors to the development of the sanitary and phytosan itary measures that relate to import restrictions that can or cannot be used by countries in respect of trade. Since these measures have been in place, other countries have sought to use them. I think one of the biggest economic traders in the world, the US, has on a number of occasions sought to use them very blatantly as trade restriction measures and their applications have been defeated on at least two occasions at the WTO. But we proceeded to actually present something and, of course, when the 1996 report was submitted, Canada disputed its finding, the disputes panel upheld Canada's position and there was an appeal. But we still did not proceed down the road to fulfil even one very important part of an import risk analysis—that is, to actually outline the communication process for many of the diseases that salmonoids would be susceptible to that were found in other parts of the world but not in Australia. Can I say also that the WTO itself had yet to finalise an import risk analysis process. It had yet to lay down the strict rules upon which a country was expected to develop or write its risk analysis.

If we look around the world to see how salmonoid diseases have been communicated from one place to another, it is very interesting. Nobody really knows how many of these diseases, which really started out in parts of Europe, were communicated to the United States, to Canada and to other parts of the world. Nobody really knows, but what you always get is the line that there is no evidence to demonstrate that this occurred as a result of a trade in product. In Europe in particular, and even now in parts of the United States and Canada, you have a salmon farming industry that is very significant. That is not to say it is not a good industry, because it actually can be a good industry. They have the basis of all of the scientific data that has been developed because it has been in their interest to develop it. Of course you would not expect them to come up with answers that say, `We have a problem with regard to the transmission of disease and it actually can occur through the transport of product.' Things like whirling disease have gone almost right around the world. It started off in Europe and has gone to the US and to Canada. It was never found in New Zealand but is now found in New Zealand, and nobody wants to acknowledge how it got there, but you will always get the excuse.

We have heard from the government that we do not have the capacity to enter into a trade war with Canada over salmon. That is simply not the point; it misses the point altogether. The reality is that there are trade laws. If the WTO is to function appropriately, we as a country have every right to take up the arguments in accordance with the trade laws, and we should do so. It does not mean that the government has to readily accept, as it has on this occasion, an outcome from the WTO. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk once again about the lack of adequate support for Australians with psychotic illnesses. Psychotic disorders cover a diverse group of illnesses that are characterised by distortions of perceptions, thinking and responses. Psychotic illness is usually linked to a loss of the ability to enjoy life and to mood disturbance and depression. Schizophrenia, bipolar and delusional disorders are included in this group and the symptoms debilitate many members of our community. The point I want to make tonight is that they are not receiving adequate care and support.

speech.para: The National Survey of Mental Health and Wellbeing, established by the Commonwealth Department of Health and Aged Care back in 1996, painted a bleak picture for over 100,000 Australians living with long-term psychotic illness. It told us just how common mental illness is in our communities. SANE Australia was invited by the mental health branch to respond to a follow-up study of over 1,000 people and it published the results in a report entitled A SANE response . These members of our community are suffering and they are more likely to be the victims rather than the perpetrators of violence. They are often homeless and they are missing out on suitable accommodation and much needed rehabilitation and recreation.

As most people now receive treatment for psychotic illnesses outside a hospital setting, the report says that effective management procedures should include in-patient and outpatient hospital care, specialist community treatment and support services. It is also important for these people to have regular and ongoing contact with a general practitioner and they should be encouraged to be active participants in community activities.

We should be able to expect that government health services will help people with psychosis to manage their illness. Yet half of those surveyed reported that when they needed a particular government service in the past 12 months they were unable to receive assistance.

SANE also found that services provided by government agencies were not as helpful as church based and other non-government ones. There is an increased need for community based support and education programs. Drop-in centres, day programs, mutual support groups and places where people can work together to reduce stigmatisation and isolation are all essential for the chronically ill to build their social skills. This support is extremely important to people with psychotic illness, especially as they grow older.

Thirty per cent of people with psychotic illnesses rent; others live in hostels or group housing. Ten per cent of those people are homeless at any point. Funding for more rehabilitation programs is absolutely essential, as only 19 per cent of people with a chronic illness attended rehabilitation programs during the past year. Yet we know that these programs are important to complement much needed clinical care and provide assistance with accommodation needs.

Funding for a range of specialist supported housing is essential. Constant shifting is detrimental to recovery or maintenance of psychotic illness. People with physical illnesses receive government funded care in their home, but only 25 per cent of those surveyed by SANE receive advice on looking after themselves at home. Forty-three per cent of those surveyed say that they are never free of symptoms and 75 per cent of those on medication suffer side effects severe enough to impair their lives. Yet disturbingly, only 19 per cent had taken part in rehabilitation services and one in 10 surveyed was homeless or living in marginal accommodation.

Many people have welcomed the closure of substandard supported residential services. However, many of these unfunded accommodation homes in Victoria, my home state, are facing closure due to increasing costs and room size restrictions being placed on them by the state government Department of Human Services. Their closure has driven many psychotically ill people out onto the streets. Where building regulations are maintained and adequate support is provided by properly trained managers and staff, these accommodation homes provide stability in what is a very fragile world for people with psychotic illness. They offer far more security than caravans or homelessness to people who are solely reliant on the disability support pension.

This year, during September-October alone, SANE identified 189 people needing full-time care. Considering that this figure did not include such heavily populated areas as the Mornington Peninsula and Mildura, this paints a grim picture indeed. People were found to be bouncing between hostels, community homes, generic hospitals and nursing homes.

SANE points out that there are not enough psycho-geriatric beds available for older people suffering from a psychotic illness. If they are placed in a nursing home, they find that other residents resent them. At Mont Park, just north of Melbourne, 26 beds are available and SANE found that beds in acute admission wards are often used. In these places, many patients were overdosed and readmissions are frequent.

It is not a pretty picture. Once again I call upon all tiers of government to recognise the needs of Australians living with psychotic illness. Like any other group, people affected by persistent psychotic illness should be consulted in the development of programs and service management plans designed for them.

SANE encourages government departments to work closely together to improve the links between existing services and to build on them so that as these people age they receive the care they need. In many older people, the symptoms become unstable and the coping strategies people have often fail as they grow older.

The matter is urgent. If we do not act now, in five or 10 years time, as SANE points out, the problem will be much worse. Again, I congratulate SANE on another important report and I urge the government to make sure the findings and recommendations do not just sit on shelves gathering dust.

talk.start.para: —As we face the end of 1999 and celebrate the commencement of the year 2000, it is appropriate for us as a nation and as a people to reflect. Tonight, I do not want to concentrate on when the new century and millennium will actually start. No doubt that will be an interesting debate that many people will have over their family barbecues, around the table, at the bar, at meetings and at Christmas parties. It will make for interesting discussion and I am not sure whether it will be resolved as to when the new century and millennium should be celebrated.

speech.para: Tonight, the chance is that this is my last speech in this parliament for 1999 and, therefore, possibly this century or millennium. I invite the Australian people to reflect on why we will be celebrating the year 2000. Why is it the year 2000 and not 2001 or indeed the year 3000? What was the commencement point for the counting of the years?

Next year, we commence the year 2000 AD, the year of our Lord. The years before AD are known as BC, or Before Christ. No other person in the history of the world has had such a significant impact on the world or, indeed, had their birth as the commencement date of the counting of years. We in this place often consider what the place in history might be for us, our political party, a particular leader and particular ministers and backbenchers, all of whom make their own individual contribution. In fairness, I simply say that none of us will even be a footnote in the history of the world in comparison to what eventuated with the birth of Christ.

The Christian faith is, of course, embraced by the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. Statistics tell us that 71 per cent of people in our Aboriginal community identify themselves as Christian and as embracing the Christian faith. An overwhelming number of migrants similarly adopt the Christian faith. Indeed, the Christian faith has had a great impact on the development of this nation. Many of our founding fathers, such as Alfred Deakin and Henry Parkes, were quite open about the role the Christian faith played in their life.

Indeed, on 1 December, when reading the Herald Sun, I saw an article by a former very distinguished minister of this parliament, James Killen, about why Ming, or Mr Menzies, is his No. 1. One of the interesting things that Sir James Killen pointed out was that Mr Menzies, in his view, had three great strengths. Allow me to quote from the article:

When he opened the National Memorial Bible House in Canberra in February 1960 he said: "The Bible is the repository of our faith and inspiration. It is the great source of faith, and that is why we should read it."
Sir James Killen then went on to say:
The spiritual strength commanded by Robert Gordon Menzies has virtually passed unobserved.
Its existence in my view . . . was vital in the building of the Menzies era.

It was also vital for, as I said before, our founding fathers, such as Alfred Deakin, who will not be known by many Australian people. They prayed and fasted for so many days to get the wording of the Australian Constitution right. Henry Parkes, who is seen as the father of our federation, said:
As we are pre-eminently a Christian people, our laws, our whole system of jurisprudence, our constitution are based on and interwoven with our Christian beliefs.

It was also important for many of the great explorers, such as Leichhardt, Sturt and Eyre, and people such as Reverend John Flynn—Flynn of the Inland—of the Royal Flying Doctor Service, who had the words painted on his plane `For Christ and country'. So many people in the development of our nation have acknowledged the importance of their faith in their endeavours.

The overwhelming embracing of the Christian faith is, unfortunately, ignored by commentators today. Indeed, there has been a trend of late to belittle the Christian faith, especially by commentators and certain writers and journalists. Indeed, sometimes even in this place, an odd interjection is made to members of the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship. One wonders whether that same lack of understanding and compassion to the Christian faith would be accepted if it were to be shown about other faiths within the community. I think not. People would be labelled as politically unreconstructed. It seems that at the moment it is fair game to be highly critical of the Christian faith, which is embraced by well over three-quarters of the Australian people.

The Christian faith has been a liberating force and a force for good. The life and example of Christ is a life that we should all seek to emulate. I fully admit—I am sure a lot of my colleagues would understand—that I fail in that regard. Madam President, you would be aware of that from time to time, especially during question time, when I may not necessarily be as unreservedly forgiving as I ought to be. As an example of leadership through service, the life and example of Christ, I believe, is one that we can all learn from.

Suicides and some of the social problems that our nation faces often have their roots in a lack of spiritual dimension in the lives of the people concerned. People see no hope or purpose beyond the immediate problem. They often see themselves as an accident, as some would have us believe this whole world is, that is, it just happened as a result of some big bang theory; they are here as a result of an accident; and if the ride is not too good, they might as well put an end to the accident they are currently experiencing; and, therefore, there is no future and no hope for them.

On the other hand, the Christian faith tells us that we are all unique and special, and that there is a purpose for us in the scheme of things as designed by the great architect of the universe. As we reflect on the last 2,000 years and the last 200-plus years, there is no doubt in my mind that the Christian faith has been an overwhelming force for good. So the purpose of my rising to my feet this evening is to invite the Australian people to consider the basis of the real reason why we will be celebrating Christmas in 17 days time and, indeed, a new year in 23 days time. Let us remember the real reason we are celebrating. I am sure that if we all do that as individuals and as a society, the future of Australia will be blessed and it will be great. My hope is that, as the new year, the new century and the new millennium commence, we do not forget the importance of the Christian faith and the Christian roots of our nation.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Science and Resources: Freedom of Information
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1484)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: (1) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made initial stage decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

(2) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made internal review decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am advised that the sum of resources across the portfolio required to provide a detailed response to these questions would represent an unwarranted diversion of the resources of the Department and portfolio agencies. Much information about Freedom of Information caseloads is available publicly in annual reports. The following information describes the arrangements for FOI decision-making in the Department.

Under section 23 of the Act, the Secretary of the Department has granted decision-making powers for FOI matters to various offices within the Department. The authorised decision-makers are either SES officers or senior legal officers. In most cases, the initial decision on access to documents is made by the SES officer whose area has jurisdiction over the documents in question. An internal review decision on access to documents is made by an officer other than the one who made the initial decision on access. As a general rule, internal review decisions on access are made at the division head level. The Secretary has issued a Departmental instruction which is designed to ensure that FOI requests are processed in a timely manner. The Department has provided its officers with FOI training and its legal sections coordinate the Department's FOI requests and provide advice on the proper handling of those requests. The qualifications, experience and employment grades of FOI decision makers are not recorded on the Department's FOI files.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 12 October 1999:

question.para: For each of the past 10 financial years:
(a) how much Commonwealth money was spent on tree planting through programs including Landcare, salinity programs and Natural Heritage Trust;
(b) state by state, how many trees and what area of vegetation was planted;
(c) what proportion of the plantings have been assessed to see whether they survived;
(d) what proportion have survived;
(e) how much Commonwealth money was spent on protecting remnant native vegetation;
(f) what area of native vegetation was protected; and
(g) state by state, what area of native vegetation was cleared.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Precise data at the level of detail requested by the honourable senator is not available due to the range of programs and agencies addressing revegetation over the period in question and the fact that tree planting is rarely the sole activity of projects. This makes it difficult to apportion investment separately or directly to tree plantings.
The following responses provide the best available information against each inquiry.

Investment in on-ground revegetation and remnant protection projects across Commonwealth programs, for the period 1989-90 until commencement of the Natural Heritage Trust, is estimated to have been approximately $6.5 million per annum. This figure covers those programs which are broadly comparable with Bushcare, and does not include investment in commercial forestry and farm forestry projects.

Since commencement of the Natural Heritage Trust, investment through Bushcare in projects for which the primary activity was on-ground action (revegetation, regeneration and remnant protection for both biodiversity conservation and sustainable production) was approximately $14.6 million for 1997-98 and $26.3 million for 1998-99. There are elements of other programs, including others funded under the NHT, which are achieving vegetation outcomes, but there is insufficient data on those outputs at this stage.

For the period 1989-90 to the commencement of the Natural Heritage Trust, the estimated total area directly revegetated or protected through Commonwealth vegetation initiatives, based on information which can be directly verified, was at least 5,000 hectares per annum.
From the commencement of the Natural Heritage Trust in 1997 until January 1999, it is estimated from project progress reports, that there has been

direct revegetation and remnant protection activity through Bushcare projects of about 132,500 hectares. It is estimated that a similar area has been revegetated and protected under the National Landcare Program. Note that these figures are from project reports written prior to January 1999, and there has been significant activity since then. In addition, this data comes from the first six months of what are often three year projects, so the bulk of the outputs are yet to be achieved. There has also been significant revegetation through programs such as the Murray-Darling 2001 Initiative, Rivercare, and the Endangered Species Program.
No information is available on the survival rates of vegetation established by pre- Natural Heritage Trust programs.

For Natural Heritage Trust funded programs, a proportion of projects has been assessed each year by State Natural Heritage Trust Evaluation Teams, Bushcare State Coordinators and Regional Facilitators and Bushcare Support (Greening Australia) staff. There is no aggregated national output data from these assessments.
Whilst it is too early to undertake an assessment of survival of vegetation established under Natural Heritage Trust programs, methodologies to determine survival rates are being developed.
(g) Annual rates of decrease in woody vegetation per State, determined by the Bureau of Rural Sciences in their report Land Cover Change 1990-1995, are as follows:

entry.para: Land Cover Change 1990-1995 (fire and forest management excluded) (ha/annum)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 12 October 1999:

question.para: Is the issue of exploration licences in Commonwealth marine waters a Commonwealth action for the purposes of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act; if so, how many licences were issued in the 3 years from July 1996 to June 1999, and in each case: (a) what area did the licence cover; (b) what activities were permitted under the licence; and (c) what environmental impact assessment was undertaken.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Yes, the issue of offshore petroleum exploration permits in Commonwealth marine waters is a Commonwealth action that requires consideration of environmental significance under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. However, the responsibility for deciding whether the issue of exploration permits under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 are significant actions for which a proponent should therefore be designated lies with the Joint Authorities which comprise the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources and the respective State and Northern Territory Ministers. I therefore suggest that the honourable senator direct matters pertaining to parts (a), (b) and (c) of the question to my colleague, the Minister for Industry, Sciences and Resources, who administers the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. In relation to part (c) of the question I can advise that no proponent was designated in relation to the issue of an exploration permit in Commonwealth marine waters between July 1996 and June 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Given that the United Nations (UN) and the Organisation of African Unity accept that the two parties in the conflict in Western Sahara are the Kingdom of Morocco and the Polisario Front, does the Minister recognise the authority of Polisario to represent the Western Sahara people.
(2) Does the Minister intend to formally meet representatives of Polisario, the representative body for the independence movement in Western Sahara.

(3) (a) Is the Government aware that, during September 1999, peaceful demonstrations were suppressed in Layoun, the capital of Western Sahara and that the UN has verified that Saharawis were killed, imprisoned or disappeared; and
(b) Will the Minister make representations to Morocco on this matter.
(4) Will the Government provide any humanitarian aid to the 165,000 Saharawi refugees who are living in south west Algeria in harsh conditions.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Australia considers the Polisario Front to be representative of an important body of West Saharan opinion, but the United Nations-sponsored referendum due to be held in July 2000 is designed to clarify the wishes of the population of Western Sahara on the issue of self-determination.

(2) Dealings occur with Polisario on an informal basis in New York, and Australian parliamentarians and officials meet with Polisario Front representatives informally. Since many Polisario representatives also hold Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR) positions, Australian Ministers do not formally receive them, because to do so might be presented as Australian acceptance of the SADR as the government of Western Sahara.

(3) (a) There was a press report of incidents at that time which indicated that a number of demonstrators were injured. Although it was reported that no-one was killed, the article stated that 27 Moroccans were given jail sentences of 10-15 years for their actions. The Australian Government is not aware that the UN has made any formal reference to the incidents, nor to its knowledge, has any of the major international human rights bodies drawn attention to them. The Australian Government remains concerned over the human rights situation in the Western Sahara as part of its overall commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights internationally.

(b) The Government has made representations to the Moroccan authorities on individual cases of alleged human rights abuses in the Western Sahara which have been brought to its attention, including through a longstanding arrangement whereby Amnesty International "Urgent Action" cases are considered and, where appropriate, pursued by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on behalf of the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group. The Australian Embassy in Paris, which has responsibility for Morocco, has made representations to the Moroccan authorities on these cases and will continue to do so where appropriate.

(4) The Australian Government has no plans to provide assistance to the Saharawi refugees in Algeria. The Australian aid program focuses on the humanitarian needs within our immediate region. East Timor, in particular, is currently taking a large proportion of our humanitarian assistance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 22 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Has an agreement been made between the governments of Victoria, Tasmania and the Commonwealth about the environmental assessment of the Duke Energy proposal for a gas pipeline to Tasmania; if so: (a) what are the terms of the agreement; and (b) can a copy be provided; if not (a) is such an agreement being, or to be, negotiated; and (b) when.

(2) (a) Under what conditions was Deal Island handed over to the Tasmania Government; and (b) is there a written agreement; if so: (i) what are the terms of the agreement, and (ii) can a copy be provided.

(3) (a) Was the transfer of Deal Island to the Tasmanian Government contingent on a marine reserve being created in the surrounding waters; and (b) has any progress been made towards creating a reserve.
(4) (a) How much money did the Commonwealth give Tasmania for managing Deal Island; and (b) for what specific purposes and under what conditions.
(5) What actions by the Commonwealth would require environmental assessment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act in relation to the Duke Energy gas pipeline proposals.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Tasmanian Natural Gas Project was designated under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 by the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator the Hon Nick Minchin, on 21 May 1999. Several aspects of the project proposal have evolved since designation. Preliminary discussions regarding the environmental assessment of the project have been held between the relevant government authorities at officer level. However, no formal agreement has yet been made regarding cooperative assessment arrangements. It is expected that a formal agreement about cooperative environmental assessment arrangements will be reached once the details of the project are finalised.

(2) (a) The conditions relating to the transfer of Deal Island from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) to the Tasmanian Government were defined in a Heads of Agreement dated 9 April 1998.

(b) Yes. (i) The terms of the agreement essentially provided for the transfer of the island to the State for the sum of $1 with the State agreeing to conserve and manage the property under terms prepared in consultation with the Australian Heritage Commission. (ii) An extract of the agreement has been provided to the honourable senator. Further copies are available from the Senate Table Office.
(3) (a) The transfer of Deal Island from AMSA to the Tasmanian Government was not contingent on the creation of a marine reserve in the surrounding waters.

(b) The Commonwealth understands that the waters surrounding Deal Island are currently being evaluated for protection as a marine reserve by the Tasmanian Government. Further information about this process should be sought from the Tasmanian Government.
(4) No funds were provided by the Commonwealth to the Tasmanian Government for managing Deal Island in association with the transfer agreement.

(5) Several actions by the Commonwealth could trigger environmental assessment of the proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. These include the potential need for approval in terms of the Government's foreign investment policy, and the provision of a pipeline licence for the Bass Strait section of the proposed pipeline. Environmental assessment of the proposal in this case has been triggered by the decision of the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources to grant the project Major Projects Facilitation Status.

subdebateinfo.title: Prime Minister's Sydney Office: Tenders for Radio Studio
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1750)

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 2 November 1999:

question.para: (1) Has a radio studio been constructed in the Prime Minister's office at 70 Phillip Street, Sydney; if so: (a) was the contract the subject of a tender process; and (b) who managed the tender process.
(2) (a) When were tenders called; (b) how many tenders were received; (c) who was the successful tenderer; and (d) what was the contracted price for the work.
(3) Was there any variation between the contract price and the final price; if so: (a) what was the size of the price overrun; and (b) what was the basis of the price overrun.
(4) Did the Commonwealth meet the full cost of constructing the facility.
(5) Did the proposal to construct the studio come from the Prime Minister's office or the department; if not, who proposed that the studio be constructed.

(6) Was the construction of the radio studio the subject of any discussions or consultations with any radio station; if so: (a) which radio stations were consulted; (b) what was the nature of those consultations or discussions; (c) who undertook those consultations or discussions on behalf of the Prime Minister; and (d) who undertook those consultations or discussions on behalf of the radio stations.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1)—(6) I am advised that a radio studio has not been constructed in the Prime Minister's Office at 70 Phillip Street, Sydney. The facility to which the question relates is presumably the media room that was set up during the week ending 4 September 1998 in the Commonwealth Parliamentary Offices at 70 Phillip Street, Sydney, which is on a different floor to the Prime Minister's Office. I am advised that it would not be accurate to describe the facility as a studio, since it consists of a normal office equipped with a broadcast quality telecommunications line and portable audio broadcasting equipment. This equipment can be connected to the line to enable a person in the room to give radio interviews as arranged with radio stations.
The lease cost of the line is $143 per month, which is paid by the Department of Finance and Administration.

Most of the current equipment dates back to October 1995, when it was purchased as a replacement for older equipment dating back into the 1980s. The purchase cost in October 1995 was $3,328. I am advised that the current and original equipment was used by the two previous Prime Ministers to participate in radio interviews from either the Lodge or the Prime Minister's office in Parliament House.

When the current equipment was set up in the Commonwealth Parliamentary Offices in September 1998, the General Manager of the Ministerial and Parliamentary Services Group, Department of Finance and Administration wrote to Ministers and Shadow Ministers informing them of the media room's availability and advising them of the booking procedure to make use of this facility.

subdebateinfo.title: East Timor: Allowances to Departmental Officers
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1751)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 November 1999:

question.para: (1) What allowances are paid to departmental personnel currently working in East Timor.
(2) Do the above payments vary with seniority; if so, what is the range of these allowances.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: According to records held by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the answer to the Honourable Member's question as follows:
(1) Departmental personnel currently working in East Timor receive Overseas Living Allowance, Difficult Post Allowance and Settling-in Allowance. One officer receives Language Proficiency Allowance.

(2) (a) Overseas Living Allowance varies depending on the salary of the officer and the cumulative length of overseas service. Departmental personnel currently working in East Timor receive between $19,860 and $28,910 per year in Overseas Living Allowance.
(b) Difficult Post Allowance does not vary with seniority. Departmental personnel currently working in East Timor receive $19,214 per year in Difficult Post Allowance.

(c) Settling-in Allowance varies depending on the seniority of the officer. Departmental personnel currently working in East Timor receive between $48 to $53 per day. Normally Settling-in Allowance is paid for up to six weeks until an officer finds permanent accommodation. Payments beyond six weeks are granted where necessary, in which case the need for the Allowance is kept under review.
(d) Language Proficiency Allowance does not vary with seniority. The officer currently working in East Timor receives $2,515 per year in Language Proficiency Allowance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 November 1999:

question.para: (1) What allowances are paid to military personnel currently engaged in peacekeeping activities in East Timor.
(2) Do the above payments vary with rank; if so, what is the range of these allowances.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to this question from the honourable senator is:

answer.para: (1) The allowances and benefits paid to military personnel currently serving in East Timor are outlined below.

(a) The Deployment Allowance payable for service in East Timor is $57.83 per day. Other allowances such as Field, Seagoing and Hard Lying Allowance may also be payable depending on the nature of the members' service.

(b) To preserve the integrity of these allowances, the East Timor Peace Enforcement Allowance (ETPEA) is structured so that it embraces the amounts payable for Deployment, Field, Seagoing and Hard Lying Allowances yet it provides a `top up' to a total of all allowances to $125 per day. That is the quantum of the ETPEA varies according to the total of other allowances payable but caps the maximum to $125 per day. ETPEA is payable for each day or part of a day a member is within the Area of Operations.
(c) All salary and allowances paid to Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel for service in East Timor are exempt from income tax.

(d) The Minister for Defence has declared service in East Timor as `warlike', for the purposes of subsection 5C(1) of the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986. The following lists those provisions for which personnel in East Timor on warlike service will be eligible.

ADF personnel in East Timor have dual eligibility with coverage under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Benefits include access to severe injury adjustment, superannuation and compensation for loss of capacity to remain in the ADF.

Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 they are entitled to disability pensions for injury or disease caused by that service and lifetime medical treatment for any such disability. The determination of the casual connection is on the more generous standard of proof applicable to operational service. The Statements of Principles of the Repatriation Medical Authority apply to all claims.
There is a general and universal rule that compensation under both schemes are matched against each other to achieve the best outcome but avoiding a doubling of benefits.

Should any of our personnel lose their lives a widow/er would be eligible for the full benefits of a widow/er's pension, including health cover, and financial support and full health cover for dependant children through the Veterans' Children Education Scheme (VCES). There are also VCES benefits, but not health cover, for those dependants whose veteran parent may become entitled to Special Rate of EDA.
Members of the ADF International Force in East Timor (INTERFET) will have eligibility for a service pension in case of invalidity or later at age 60 subject to normal means testing provisions.
Health issues + Access to treatment for difficult to diagnose illnesses
On 5 July 1999, I issued a media release concerning ADF personnel involved in deployments overseas. The members of INTERFET are potentially exposed to a range of operational, environ-
mental, and occupational threats different to those involved in peacetime service in Australia. The effects of some of these threats may not be readily apparent on their return to Australia.

The Government is adopting a strategy, to be delivered by the Departments of Defence and Veterans' Affairs, to enable the Department of Veterans' Affairs to provide early treatment of veterans suffering from acute symptoms but difficult to diagnose conditions. This will allow any veterans to obtain acute care for the symptoms of medical and psychiatric conditions that might not be able to be diagnosed within a reasonable time by the medical community.

The Department will also provide free access to treatment for a number of conditions, including post traumatic stress disorder. Members of INTERFET and their dependants will also have access to the services provided by the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service.

Any death on active service will be recorded on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial. Commemoration of the sacrifice made would also be available from the Office of Australian War Graves.
(e) Personnel serving in East Timor will also attract an entitlement under the Defence Home Owner Scheme.
(f) All members will accrue War Service Leave of 1.5 days for each completed month of service in East Timor.
(2) Apart from salary, the above allowances do not vary with rank.
